original: Govind Kaul / Pradeśasaṃgraha
analyzed: govind kaul pradeśa saṃgraha
translated: The Compilation of the Regions by Govinda Kaula

original: Kaśmīrā Maṇḍalam
analyzed: kaśmīrāḥ maṇḍalam
translated: The Mandala of Kashmir

original: oṃ śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ /
analyzed: om śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ
translated: Om, salutations to the illustrious Ganesha.

original: paṇḍitakalhaṇakṛtarājataraṅgiṇyāṃ prathame taraṅge ślokasaṃ kaśmīrā /🔽asyāḥ satīsara iti dvitīyaṃ nāma /
analyzed: paṇḍita kalhaṇa kṛta rājataraṅgiṇyām prathame taraṅge ślokasam kaśmīrā  asyāḥ satīsaraḥ iti dvitīyam nāma
translated: In the Rajatarangini composed by Pandit Kalhana, in the first wave, there are 100 verses.🔽This has a second name Satirasa.

original: asya niruktiḥ /
analyzed: asya niruktiḥ
translated: The etymology of this is as follows.

original: kaṃ jalaṃ śmīrati calaty asmād iti śmīra smīra calane iti dhātor auṇādikaṃ rūpam /
analyzed: kam jalam śmīrati calati asmāt iti śmīra smīra calane iti dhātoḥ auṇādikam rūpam
translated: Kam means water, and smirat means it moves from this, so smirat is a form derived from the root smirat meaning to move.

original: tathā ca nīlamate
analyzed: tathā ca nīlamate
translated: And thus in the Nilamata

original: kaṃ vāri halinā yasmād deśād asmād apākṛtam /
analyzed: kam vāri halinā yasmāt deśāt asmāt apākṛtam
translated: Kam means water, and from which country this water has been removed,

original: ataḥ sarvajagatkhyātaṃ kaśmīrākhyaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: atas sarva jagat khyātam kaśmīra ākhyam bhaviṣyati
translated: from that it will be known in the entire world as Kashmir.

original: anyac ca calanaṃ sampādanam ity api tanmatenaivāvagamyate /
analyzed: anyat ca calanam sampādanam iti api tad matena evā avagamyate
translated: And the other meaning of smirat is also understood to mean to accomplish according to the same view.

original: tathā ca kaśyapena sampāditasyāpi maṇḍalasya kaśmīrā iti nāma /
analyzed: tathā ca kaśyapena sampāditasya api maṇḍalasya kaśmīrāḥ iti nāma
translated: And thus even the mandala accomplished by Kashyapa is named Kashmir.

original: etad api nīlamatād evāvabudhyate /
analyzed: etat api nīla matāt evā avabudhyate
translated: This is also understood from the Nilamata itself.

original: tathā hi
analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus it is said:

original: kaḥ prajāpatir uddiṣṭaḥ kaśyapaś ca prajāpatiḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ prajāpatiḥ uddiṣṭaḥ kaśyapaḥ ca prajāpatiḥ
translated: Ka is designated as Prajapati, and Kashyapa is also Prajapati.

original: atas tadākhyayā tīrthaṃ kāśmīrākhyaṃ bhaviṣyati // iti /
analyzed: atas tad ākhyayā tīrtham kāśmīra ākhyam bhaviṣyati iti
translated: Therefore, by his name, the tirtha will be known as Kashmira.

original: asya kaśmīrāpadasya kaśīra iti kāśmīrikabhāṣāyāṃ nāma vartate /
analyzed: asya kaśmīrā padasya kaśīraḥ iti kāśmīrika bhāṣāyām nāma vartate
translated: In the Kashmiri language, the name of this Kashmiri misfortune is Kashīra.

original: ata eva kaśmīrotpannasya puṃsaḥ kaśur iti nāmāsti /
analyzed: atas eva kaśmīra utpannasya puṃsaḥ kaśuḥ iti nāma asti
translated: For this very reason, a person born in Kashmir has the name Kashur.

original: punaś cānyamatena kaśmīrāpadaniruktau bahavo vibhedāḥ santi /
analyzed: punar ca anya matena kaśmīrā pada niruktau bahavaḥ vibhedāḥ santi
translated: Moreover, according to another opinion, there are many variations in the etymological explanation of Kashmiri misfortune.

original: tathā ca pārisekānuvādavidaḥ kecana kaśyapamar iti kathayanti /
analyzed: tathā ca pāriseka anuvāda vidaḥ kecana iti kathayanti
translated: In the same way, some who know the recitation of the Pariśeka say Kashyapamṛ.

original: tanmatena kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ marpadasya gṛham ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tad matena kaśmīra bhāṣāyām marpadasya gṛham iti arthaḥ
translated: According to that opinion, in the Kashmiri language, the word mṛ means house.

original: tathā ca kaśyapasya gṛham iti yāvat /
analyzed: tathā ca kaśyapasya gṛham iti yāvat
translated: Thus, it means the house of Kashyapa.

original: anye tu kaśūr iti kaścid rākṣasaḥ pūrvasmin kāle babhūva /
analyzed: anye tu kaśūḥ iti kaścid rākṣasaḥ pūrvasmin kāle babhūva
translated: Others say that in ancient times there was a certain demon named Kashur.

original: tasyaiva rakṣasasya marpadavācyā ekā apsarāḥ parīpadavācyā taddhastagatāpy āsīt /
analyzed: tasya eva rakṣasasya marpada vācyā ekā apsarāḥ parīpada vācyā tad hasta gatā api āsīt
translated: That demon had two celestial nymphs, one called mṛ and the other called parī, who were in his possession.

original: tābhyām eva sarvatra bambhramyamāṇābhyāṃ yad atra manohare maṇḍale svanivāsārthaṃ sthitir āsāditā /
analyzed: tābhyām eva sarvatra bambhramyamāṇābhyām yat atra manohare maṇḍale sva nivāsa artham sthitiḥ āsāditā
translated: Wandering everywhere, they found a place to dwell in this delightful mandala.

original: ataḥ kaśmar iti tadākhyayaiva prathām āgatyāyaṃ deśaḥ sarvajagatprasiddhaḥ sampanna ityādi svapustakeṣu likhanti /
analyzed: atas kaśmar iti tad ākhyayā eva prathām āgatya ayam deśaḥ sarva jagat prasiddhaḥ sampannaḥ ityādi sva pustakeṣu likhanti
translated: Therefore, this country became famous by that very name Kashmīra and became well-known to the whole world. They write this and more in their own books.

original: paraṃ tu asmin nāmani grāmīṇānāṃ nāgarikānāṃ ca kvāpy uccāraṇādiviṣaye bhedo nāstīti śam //
analyzed: param tu asmin nāmani grāmīṇānām nāgarikānām ca kvāpi uccāraṇa ādi viṣaye bhedaḥ na asti iti śam
translated: But in this name, there is no difference at all in the pronunciation etc. of the villagers and the city-dwellers. Peace!

original: Nīlanāgaḥ Varanāgo vā
analyzed: nīla nāgaḥ varanāgaḥ vā
translated: The Blue Naga or the Excellent Naga

original: ślo nambara nāgādhīśena nīlena /
analyzed: nambara nāga adhīśena nīlena
translated: The sloka is composed by the Naga Lord, the Blue One.

original: ayaṃ nīlābhidho nāgaḥ kaśyaparṣiputraḥ /
analyzed: ayam nīla abhidhaḥ nāgaḥ kaśyapa ṛṣi putraḥ
translated: This Naga named Blue is the son of the sage Kashyapa.

original: kaśmīrasthāne ka nāgānām adhipatiḥ /
analyzed: kaśmīrasthāne ka nāgānām adhipatiḥ
translated: He is the lord of the Nagas in the land of Kashmir.

original: tena kaśyapena svakīyapitrā kaśmīrāsampādanakāla eva teṣām asaṃkhyānāṃ nāgānām ādhipatye sukarmaśikṣāyai kukarmaṇo nivṛttaye cābhiṣiktaḥ /
analyzed: tena kaśyapena svakīya pitrā kaśmīra a sampādana kāle eva teṣām asaṃkhyānām nāgānām ādhipatye su karma śikṣāyai ku karmaṇaḥ nivṛttaye ca abhiṣiktaḥ
translated: By his own father Kashyapa, at the time of establishing Kashmir, he was consecrated as the lord of those innumerable Nagas for the sake of good deeds and for the cessation of bad deeds.

original: śāhūbād puragaṇo yo 'dhunā śrīraṇavīrasiṃghapurā iti nāma dhārayati tasminn eva puragaṇe
analyzed: pura gaṇaḥ yaḥ dhunā iti nāma dhārayati tasmin eva pura gaṇe
translated: In that very city called Shahubad, which now bears the name of Shri Ranveer Singh Pura,

original: pīr pañcāl iti khyāto yo 'yaṃ kaśmīradeśasya pañcanadadeśasya ca madhye sīmaiva gaṇanīyatām🔽āgataḥ parvato 'sti /
analyzed: iti khyātaḥ yaḥ yam kaśmīra deśasya pañcanada deśasya ca madhye sīmā eva gaṇanīyatām 🔽āgataḥ parvataḥ sti
translated: In the middle of the Kashmir country and the Panchanada country, there is a mountain known as Peer Panchal, which has become the boundary to be counted.

original: tasmād eva parvatād ardhakrośamite kaśmīraunmukhyabhājimārge mahān aṣṭakoṇo 'gādhaḥ śītalajalaś ca nīlanāganivāsasthānaṃ jalāśayo vartate /
analyzed: tasmāt eva parvatāt ardha krośa mite kaśmīra aunmukhya bhāji mārge mahān aṣṭa koṇaḥ gādhaḥ śītala jalaḥ ca nīla nāga nivāsa sthānam jalāśayaḥ vartate
translated: At a distance of half a krośa from that mountain, on the road leading towards Kashmir, there is a great, eight-sided, deep, cool-watered lake, the abode of the blue serpent, Nīlanāga.

original: asya varanāgaḥ nīlanāgaḥ vīranāgaḥ ityādīni nāmāni santi /
analyzed: asya varanāgaḥ nīlanāgaḥ vīranāgaḥ ityādīni nāmāni santi
translated: This serpent has various names such as Varṇāga, Nīlanāga, Vīranāga, and so on.

original: tatra varanāgaḥ uttamanāgaḥ nīlanāgaḥ nīlanāmānāgaḥ nīlavarṇajalavān nāgaś ca vīranāgaḥ vīraś cāsau nāga iti grāmīṇas tu asya sthānasya vernāga
analyzed: tatra vara nāgaḥ uttama nāgaḥ nīla nāgaḥ nīla nāmā nāgaḥ nīla varṇa jalavān nāgaḥ ca vīra nāgaḥ vīraḥ ca asau nāgaḥ iti grāmīṇaḥ tu asya sthānasya vernāga
translated: There, Varṇāga means the best serpent, Nīlanāga means the serpent named Nīla, and Nīlavarṇajala means the serpent with blue-colored water. Vīranāga means the hero and the serpent. But the villagers call this place Vīranāga.

original: iti nāma kathayanti /
analyzed: iti nāma kathayanti
translated: They say that this is the name.

original: eto vernāg evādhunā grāmanāmāpy asti /
analyzed: etaḥ vernāc eva adhunā grāma nāma api asti
translated: Now, Vīranāga is also the name of a village.

original: varanāgaveranāgayoś ca sādṛśyam evoccāraṇe 'pi vartate /
analyzed: vara nāga vera nāgayoḥ ca sādṛśyam eva uccāraṇe vartate
translated: And there is a similarity in pronunciation between Varṇāga and Vīranāga.

original: kecana bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitāmatāmatāśrayiṇo vīrī iti grāmasya nāmoktā vīrīviṣayasthito nāgaḥ vīrīnāga iti nāma kathayanti /
analyzed: kecana bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitā amata amata āśrayiṇaḥ vīrī iti grāmasya nāma uktāḥ vīrī viṣaya sthitaḥ nāgaḥ vīrīnāgaḥ iti nāma kathayanti
translated: Some who follow the teachings of the Bhṛṅgīśa Saṃhitā say that the name of the village is Vīrī, and the serpent dwelling in the Vīrī region is called the Vīrīnāga.

original: asmiñ jalāśaye matsyā asaṃkhyāḥ santi /
analyzed: asmin jalāśaye matsyāḥ asaṃkhyāḥ santi
translated: In this lake, there are countless fish.

original: punaś ca asya jalāśayasya pāścāttye taṭa ekā bṛhacchālā purātanakālīnena jyahāṃgīrarājñā sampāditā yasyām ādhunikarājñā jīrṇoddhārādikaṃ niramīyata
analyzed: punar ca asya jalāśayasya pāścāttye taṭe ekā bṛhat śālā purātana kālīnena jyahāṃgīra rājñā sampāditā yasyām ādhunika rājñā jīrṇa uddhāra ādikam niramīyata
translated: And again, on the western bank of this lake, there is a large hall built by an ancient king named Jyaha Angira, in which the modern king has carried out repairs and so on.

original: atraika ārāmo 'pi purātanarājasampādito bhavati //
analyzed: atra ekaḥ ārāmaḥ pi purātana rāja sampāditaḥ bhavati
translated: Here there is also an old garden built by an ancient king.

original: Kapaṭeśvaraḥ
translated: Kapatishvara

original: ślo nambara kāṣṭharūpam umāpatim /
analyzed: umāpatim
translated: The one who is the husband of Uma in the form of a log,

original: kāṣṭharūpaṃ kāṣṭhākṛtim umāyāḥ pārvatyāḥ patir bhartā śivaḥ /
analyzed: kāṣṭha rūpam kāṣṭha ākṛtim umāyāḥ pārvatyāḥ patiḥ bhartā śivaḥ
translated: The husband, the lord of Uma, Parvati, in the form of a log, in the form of wood.

original: taṃ śivaṃ samyak sparśaṃ kurvatāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ bhogaprāptir bhavati /
analyzed: tam śivam samyak sparśam kurvatām puruṣāṇām bhoga prāptiḥ bhavati
translated: For those men who touch that Shiva properly, they attain enjoyment.

original: purā sarvair munibhiḥ prārthitena śivena teṣām evānugrahārthaṃ kapaṭenaiva svamūrtiprākaṭyakaraṇaṃ munibhyo 'ṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: purā sarvaiḥ munibhiḥ prārthitena śivena teṣām eva anugraha artham kapaṭena eva sva mūrti prākaṭya karaṇam munibhyaḥ ṅgīkṛtam
translated: In ancient times, Shiva, who was requested by all the sages, agreed to manifest his form deceitfully for the sake of granting them grace.

original: athaitādṛśaṃ śivād varaṃ labdhvāgatya cāsmin sthāne kāṣṭhā eva jale vivartamānā dṛṣṭāḥ /
analyzed: atha etādṛśam śivāt varam labdhvā āgatya ca asmin sthāne kāṣṭhāḥ eva jale vivartamānāḥ dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: Then, having obtained such a boon from Shiva, the logs were seen floating in the water at this place.

original: ato 'sya tīrthībhūtasya jalāśayasya kapaṭeśvara iti nāma kṛtam /
analyzed: tīrthībhūtasya jalāśayasya kapaṭeśvaraḥ iti nāma kṛtam
translated: Therefore, this holy lake was named Kapatishvara.

original: adhunāpy asmiñ jalāśaya eko bṛhatkāṣṭho darīdṛśyate /
analyzed: adhunā api asmin jalāśaye ekaḥ bṛhat kāṣṭhaḥ darīdṛśyate
translated: Even now, in this lake, a large log can be seen.

original: nīlamate 'pi kapaṭeśvaramāhātmyavarṇane kapaṭena darśanaṃ dāsyāmi bhavadbhya iti munīn prati śivenoktaṃ yadā tadaivāgatya munibhir asmiñ jale
analyzed: nīla mate kapaṭeśvara māhātmya varṇane kapaṭena darśanam dāsyāmi bhavadbhyaḥ iti munīn prati śivena uktam yadā tadā eva āgatya munibhiḥ asmin jale
translated: In the Nīlamaṇi, in the description of the greatness of Kapaṭeśvara, when Śiva said to the sages, I will give you a vision through deception, the sages came and in this water

original: kāṣṭhākṛteḥ śivasya darśanaṃ kṛtam /
analyzed: kāṣṭhā ākṛteḥ śivasya darśanam kṛtam
translated: In the Nīlamaṇi, in the description of the greatness of Kapaṭeśvara, when Śiva said to the sages, I will show myself to you through deception, the sages came and saw Śiva in the form of a log in this water.

original: ato 'sya sthānasya kapaṭeśvara iti nāma sampannam /
analyzed: atas sya sthānasya kapaṭeśvaraḥ iti nāma sampannam
translated: Therefore, this place came to be known as Kapaṭeśvara.

original: etādṛśy eva kathā vistare soktāsti /
analyzed: etādṛśī eva kathā vistare sā uktā asti
translated: Such a story is told in detail.

original: grāmīṇāḥ kaśmīrabhāṣayā asya sthānasya koṭyher iti nāma vadanti /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ kaśmīra bhāṣayā asya sthānasya koṭyheḥ iti nāma vadanti
translated: The villagers call this place by the name Koṭyher in the Kashmiri language.

original: ata eva kuṭahārapuragaṇo 'pi anenaiva nāmnā prakhyātiṃ prāptaḥ yasminn ayam eko grāmaḥ koṭyher iti nāmnādhunāpi kathyamāno 'sti /
analyzed: atas eva anena eva nāmnā prakhyātim prāptaḥ yasmin ayam ekaḥ grāmaḥ koṭyheḥ iti nāmnā adhunā api kathyamānaḥ sti
translated: For this very reason, the Kuṭahāra-pura-gaṇa has also become famous by this very name, in which this one village is still called by the name Koṭyher.

original: ayaṃ puragaṇaḥ pūrvoktāt śāhūbādapuragaṇād adhastāt krośacatuṣṭayena bhavati /
analyzed: ayam pura gaṇaḥ pūrva uktāt śāhūbāda pura gaṇāt adhastāt krośa catuṣṭayena bhavati
translated: This pura-gaṇa is four krośas below the previously mentioned Śāhubāda-pura-gaṇa.

original: asminn eva achyabal iti sthānaṃ sarvajanamate priyaṃ sarvataḥ prakhyātaṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: asmin eva iti sthānam sarva jana mate priyam sarvatas prakhyātam ca bhavati
translated: In this very place, the place called Achyabal is dear to the minds of all people and is famous everywhere.

original: grāmīṇā asya jalāśayasya saṅkarṣaṇ nāg iti nāmāpi vadanto vartante //
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ asya jalāśayasya saṅkarṣan nāc iti nāma api vadantaḥ vartante
translated: The villagers also call this water-pond by the name Saṅkaṣaṇa Nāga.

original: Pāpasūdanatīrtham
translated: The Pāpasūdanatīrtha

original: ślo nambara pāpasūdanaṃ tīrthāntaḥ /
analyzed: pāpa sūdanam tīrtha antaḥ
translated: The Pāpasūdanatīrtha is within another tīrtha.

original: pāpāni sūdayati nāśayati yat tat pāpasūdanaṃ pāpanāśakaṃ tīrtham /
analyzed: pāpāni sūdayati nāśayati yat tat pāpa sūdanam pāpa nāśakam tīrtham
translated: That which destroys, annihilates, sins is the Pāpasūdanatīrtha, the tīrtha that destroys sins.

original: tasmiṃs tīrthasaṃspṛśatāṃ snānaṃ kurvatāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ muktiprāptir bhavati /
analyzed: tasmin tīrtha saṃspṛśatām snānam kurvatām puruṣāṇām mukti prāptiḥ bhavati
translated: For men who touch that tīrtha and perform ablutions in it, there is attainment of liberation.

original: atrāpi mahāñ jalāśayo vartate /
analyzed: atra api mahān jalāśayaḥ vartate
translated: Here also there is a great reservoir of water.

original: kaśmīrabhāṣāyām apy asya jalāśayasya pāpaharaṇ nāg iti nāma sarvatra grāmīṇāḥ kathayanti /
analyzed: kaśmīra bhāṣāyām api asya jalāśayasya nāk iti nāma sarvatra grāmīṇāḥ kathayanti
translated: In the Kashmiri language, the villagers everywhere call this reservoir Pāpaharana Nāg.

original: ayaṃ jalāśayaḥ pūrvoktāt kuṭahārapargaṇād alpāntaravartini vāmapārśvapuragaṇe ādhunike kāle khourpor iti khyāta puragaṇe 'sti /
analyzed: ayam jalāśayaḥ pūrva uktāt alpa antara vartini vāma pārśva pura gaṇe ādhunike kāle iti khyāta pura gaṇe sti
translated: This reservoir is located in the modern town called Khourpur, which is situated in the Vāmapārśvapura town, a short distance from the previously mentioned Kuthārpargaṇa.

original: tatrāpi sālīpāṃjamul iti khyātaṃ grāmadvayam asti /
analyzed: tatra api sālīpāṃjamul iti khyātam grāma dvayam asti
translated: There too, there are two villages known as Sālīpāñjamul.

original: tayor eva madhye 'yaṃ pāpaharaṇ nāg ityabhidho jalāśayo vartate /
analyzed: tayoḥ eva madhye yam nāk iti abhidhaḥ jalāśayaḥ vartate
translated: In the middle of those two, there is a reservoir called Pāpaharana Nāg.

original: atra pāpasūdanapāpaharaṇapadayoḥ sadṛśārthatvena saṃskṛte kaśmīrabhāṣāyām api asmin pade tādṛśo bhedo nāsti /
analyzed: atra pāpa sūdana pāpa haraṇa padayoḥ sadṛśa artha tvena saṃskṛte kaśmīra bhāṣāyām api asmin pade tādṛśaḥ bhedaḥ na asti
translated: Here, the words Pāpasūdana and Pāpaharana have similar meanings. In Sanskrit and the Kashmiri language, there is no such distinction in this word.

original: ayaṃ jalāśayaś catuṣkoṇo nīlanāgād alpataro 'pi vartate /
analyzed: ayam jalāśayaḥ catuṣkoṇaḥ nīla nāgāt alpataraḥ vartate
translated: This water reservoir is quadrangular, smaller than the Blue Naga, but it exists.

original: kadācana vāriparṇīyasya kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ muṅgol nāmāsti /
analyzed: kadācana vāriparṇīyasya kaśmīra bhāṣāyām muṅgol nāma asti
translated: Sometimes in the Kashmiri language, there is a word called mungul for water plants.

original: tathācchādito 'pi dṛśyate //
analyzed: tathā ācchāditaḥ pi dṛśyate
translated: Even though covered, it is seen.

original: Trisandhyā Devī🔽ślo nambara sandhyā devī /
analyzed: trisandhyā devī  ślo nambara sandhyā devī
translated: The goddess Trisandhya

original: samyak dhyāyate dvijātibhir yā sā sandhyā /
analyzed: samyak dhyāyate dvijātibhiḥ yā sā sandhyā
translated: The goddess Sandhya is praised by the twice-born.

original: sā cāsau devī dyotanaśīlā krīḍanaśīlā ceti asya tīrthavarasya sarvajagatprasiddhaṃ trisandhyā iti nāma sarve kathayanti /
analyzed: sā ca asau devī dyotana śīlā krīḍana śīlā ca iti asya tīrtha varasya sarva jagat prasiddham trisandhyā iti nāma sarve kathayanti
translated: She is the goddess who shines and plays, and everyone says that this best of tirthas is known as Trisandhya.

original: etat tīrthaṃ parvatasya kukṣau vartate /
analyzed: etat tīrtham parvatasya kukṣau vartate
translated: This tirtha is located in the womb of the mountain.

original: atra jalāśayo vartulākāro 'dhastāt saṃkucita uparitane bhāge vistṛtākāro bhavati /
analyzed: atra jalāśayaḥ vartula ākāraḥ dhastāt saṃkucitaḥ uparitane bhāge vistṛta ākāraḥ bhavati
translated: Here, the water reservoir is circular in shape, contracted below, and expanded above.

original: punaś cāyaṃ sadaiva śuṣko vasantakāle paripūrṇajalo grīṣmakāle trivāraṃ dine trivāraṃ rātrau ca paripūrṇajalaḥ śuṣkajalo 'pi bhavati /
analyzed: punar ca ayam sadā eva śuṣkaḥ vasanta kāle paripūrṇa jalaḥ grīṣma kāle tri vāram dine tri vāram rātrau ca paripūrṇa jalaḥ śuṣka jalaḥ bhavati
translated: Moreover, this is always dry, filled with water in the spring season, and filled with water three times a day and three times a night in the summer season, but it is also dry.

original: arthāt cañcalatayā jalavān jalābhāvavāṃś ca bhavati /
analyzed: arthāt cañcala tayā jalavān jala abhāvavān ca bhavati
translated: In other words, it has water due to its fickleness, and it also lacks water.

original: tathā coktaṃ bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitādiśāstrabhedeṣu
analyzed: tathā ca uktam bhṛṅgīśa saṃhitā ādi śāstra bhedeṣu
translated: And it is said in the different scriptures such as the Bhṛṅgīśa Saṃhitā:

original: sadā śuṣkā madhau pūrṇā grīṣme cañcalavāhinī /
analyzed: sadā śuṣkā madhau pūrṇā grīṣme cañcala vāhinī
translated: Always dry in autumn, full in spring, and flowing erratically in summer,

original: trikālavāhinī sandhyā sā sandhyā mokṣādāyinīti
analyzed: tri kāla vāhinī sandhyā sā sandhyā mokṣa ādāyinī iti
translated: The sandhyā flowing in the three times, that sandhyā bestows liberation.

original: ato grīṣmakāle jyaiṣṭhe māsi yathā prabhāte madhyāhne sāyaṃkāle ca sandhyopāsanaṃ kriyate /
analyzed: atas grīṣma kāle jyaiṣṭhe māsi yathā prabhāte madhyāhne sāyaṃkāle ca sandhyā upāsanam kriyate
translated: Therefore, in the summer season, in the month of Jyeṣṭha, just as the sandhyā worship is performed in the morning, at midday, and in the evening,

original: tathaivāsya tīrthavarasya yātrā sandhyeva bhavati /
analyzed: tathā eva asya tīrtha varasya yātrā sandhyā iva bhavati
translated: in the same way, the pilgrimage to this excellent holy place is like the sandhyā.

original: ayaṃ jalāśayo madhye pārśvayoś ca vartulākāraiḥ prastarair bharito 'sti /
analyzed: ayam jalāśayaḥ madhye pārśvayoḥ ca vartula ākāraiḥ prastaraiḥ asti
translated: This reservoir is filled with round-shaped rocks in the middle and on the sides.

original: yasmin kāle sandhyāṃ vidhāya jalaṃ śuṣkatāṃ gacchati tasmin kāle tebhya eva pāṣāṇarandhrebhya ākhavo nirgatya bhaktaiḥ pūjārthaṃ jalāśaye pātitam
analyzed: yasmin kāle sandhyām vidhāya jalam śuṣka tām gacchati tasmin kāle tebhyaḥ eva pāṣāṇa randhrebhyaḥ ākhavaḥ nirgatya bhaktaiḥ pūjā artham jalāśaye pātitam  /
translated: At the time when the sandhyā is performed and the water dries up, at that time the mice come out from those very stone holes and eat the unbroken rice and other offerings that are thrown into the reservoir by the devotees for worship.

original: akṣatādikaṃ bhakṣayanti /
analyzed: akṣata ādikam bhakṣayanti
translated: They eat the unbroken rice and other offerings.

original: asya tīrthavarasya samīpe saptarṣīṇāṃ saptajalāśayā bhavanti /
analyzed: asya tīrtha varasya samīpe saptarṣīṇām sapta jalāśayāḥ bhavanti
translated: Near this excellent holy place, there are seven reservoirs of the seven sages.

original: tebhya ekā kulyāpi nirgacchati /
analyzed: tebhyaḥ ekā kulyā api nirgacchati
translated: A small stream also flows from them.

original: sālpā nady asya parvatasthatīrthavarasyādhastād vartate /
analyzed: sā alpā nadī asya parvata stha tīrtha varasya adhastāt vartate
translated: A small river flows below this mountain-situated excellent holy place.

original: sandhyākaraṇavelāyāṃ tīrthajalaṃ jalāśayān nirgatya nadījalamadhye patati /
analyzed: sandhyā karaṇa velāyām tīrtha jalam jalāśayāt nirgatya nadī jala madhye patati
translated: At the time of the performance of the evening twilight rites, the water of the holy place comes out from the water reservoirs and falls in the middle of the river water.

original: tatra saṃgamatīrthe snānādikaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tatra saṃgamatīrthe snāna ādikam bhavati
translated: There is bathing etc. in the holy place of the confluence.

original: ayaṃ jalāśayo bhṛṅgpuragaṇe pūrvoktakuṭahārapuragaṇanikaṭavartini yo divalgāsanāmā grāmo 'sti /
analyzed: ayam jalāśayaḥ bhṛṅgpura gaṇe pūrva ukta kuṭahāra pura gaṇa nikaṭa vartini yaḥ divalgāsa nāmā grāmaḥ sti
translated: This water reservoir is in the Bhṛṅgapura group, near the previously mentioned Kuṭahāra-pura group, in the village named Divalgāsa.

original: tanmadhye khyātimad bhavati /
analyzed: tat madhye khyātimat bhavati
translated: It is famous in its middle.

original: grāmīṇāḥ kāśmīrikāś cāsya tīrthasya sundabhrār iti nāma vadanti /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ kāśmīrikāḥ ca asya tīrthasya iti nāma vadanti
translated: The villagers and Kashmiris call this holy place Sundabhṛār.

original: tatra bhrār kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ devīnāma bhavati /
analyzed: tatra bhrār kaśmīra bhāṣāyām devī nāma bhavati
translated: There, bhṛār means goddess in the Kashmiri language.

original: ataḥ sundabhrār sundaradevīty arthaḥ /🔽asya puragaṇasya bhṛṅggrāmasya ca divalgon iti grāmīṇānām uccaraṇaviṣaye vartate /
analyzed: atas sunda bhrāj sundara devī iti arthaḥ  asya pura gaṇasya bhṛṅggrāmasya ca divalgon iti grāmīṇānām uccaraṇa viṣaye vartate
translated: Therefore, Sundabhṛār means beautiful goddess.🔽This refers to the pronunciation of the villagers of this village and the Bhṛṅg village of this village group.

original: asya grāmasyādhastāt bihū jalan gām iti khyātaṃ grāmadvayaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: asya grāmasya adhastāt bihū jalan gām iti khyātam grāma dvayam bhavati
translated: Below this village, there are two famous villages called Bihu Jalangā.

original: asya tīrthavarasya śirasi eko vṛkṣaḥ pippalavṛkṣa ivopalakṣaṇībhūto 'pi vartate /
analyzed: asya tīrtha varasya śirasi ekaḥ vṛkṣaḥ pippala vṛkṣaḥ iva upalakṣaṇībhūtaḥ pi vartate
translated: On the head of this best holy place, there is a tree that is recognized like a pippala tree.

original: sandhyākaraṇavelāyāṃ jalaprādurbhāvakāle puṣpākṣatanaivedyādipātanenāpy antardhānaṃ jalam āgacchati /
analyzed: sandhyā karaṇa velāyām jala prādurbhāva kāle puṣpa akṣata naivedya ādi pātanena api antardhānam jalam āgacchati
translated: At the time of the performance of Sandhya, when water appears, by the falling of flowers, offerings, etc., the water disappears and comes back.

original: tadā jalāśayād eva jalaṃ uddhṛtya snānādikaṃ sarve kurvanti /
analyzed: tadā jalāśayāt eva jalam uddhṛtya snāna ādikam sarve kurvanti
translated: Then, they all take water from the water reservoir and perform bathing and other rituals.

original: atha dvitīyasandhyākaraṇavelāyāṃ vinītatayā pratīkṣamāṇair janair yadā sthīyate tadā jalaṃ pūrvavad bahir nirgatya saṃgamajalena militvā snānādikaṃ
analyzed: atha dvitīya sandhyā karaṇa velāyām vinīta tayā pratīkṣamāṇaiḥ janaiḥ yadā sthīyate tadā jalam pūrvavat bahis nirgatya saṃgama jalena militvā snāna ādikam
translated: Then, at the time of the performance of the second Sandhya, when people wait respectfully, the water, as before, comes out and, mixing with the water of the confluence, bathing and other rituals

original: sidhyati /🔽ye kecana daṇḍadhāriṇo rājapuruṣāḥ khaḍgādyāyudhādibhis sahaivāvinītavat sandhyākaraṇavelāyāṃ
analyzed: sidhyati  ye kecana daṇḍa dhāriṇaḥ rāja puruṣāḥ khaḍga ādi āyudha ādibhiḥ saha eva avinīta vat sandhyā karaṇa velāyām
translated: are accomplished.

original: jalāśayasyāsya taṭe 'śucitayaivāgacchanti tān aśucīn avinītāṃś ca dṛṣṭvā jalam adarśanaṃ yāti /
analyzed: jalāśayasya asya taṭe śuci tayā eva āgacchanti tān aśucīn avinītān ca dṛṣṭvā jalam adarśanam yāti
translated: Some royal officers who carry staffs, along with weapons like swords, etc., come to the bank of this water reservoir at the time of the performance of Sandhya, like ill-behaved people, with impurity itself. Seeing those impure and ill-behaved people, the water disappears.

original: ataḥ sarvathaivāyaṃ tīrthavaro 'dbhuto mānyaḥ pūjyaś cāsmin deśe khyātatamo 'pi vartate /
analyzed: atas sarvathā evā ayam tīrtha varaḥ dbhutaḥ mānyaḥ pūjyaḥ ca asmin deśe vartate
translated: Therefore, this excellent holy place is in every way wonderful, respectable, and worshipful, and is also very famous in this country.

original: ata eva
analyzed: atas eva
translated: For this very reason,

original: darśanaṃ puṇyapāpānām anvayavyatirekayor
analyzed: darśanam puṇya pāpānām anvaya vyatirekayoḥ
translated: the seeing of the effects of merit and demerit through positive and negative concomitance,

original: iti kalhaṇoktaṃ satyatayā bhāti yato 'sya puṇyavanta eva darśanaṃ prāpnuvanti /
analyzed: iti kalhaṇa uktam satya tayā bhāti yatas sya puṇyavantaḥ eva darśanam prāpnuvanti
translated: As stated by Kalhana, it is true that only the virtuous ones obtain a vision of it.

original: pāpinas tu tatra gatvāpi darśanarahitā eva pratyāgacchanti //🔽Svayambhūḥ Agniḥ
analyzed: pāpinaḥ tu tatra gatvā api darśana rahitāḥ eva pratyāgacchanti  svayambhūḥ agniḥ
translated: But the sinful ones, even after going there, return without having seen it.🔽Svayambhu: Self-existent

original: śloka nambara svayambhūr /
analyzed: śloka nambara svayambhūḥ
translated: The self-existent fire.

original: hutabhuk svayam eva na tu anyena kenāpi prajvālyamāno yo bhavati sa svayambhūḥ /
analyzed: hutabhuj svayam eva na tu anyena kena api prajvālyamānaḥ yaḥ bhavati sa svayambhūḥ
translated: The one who is self-existent, not kindled by anyone else, is Svayambhu.

original: etādṛśo yo hutabhuk agniḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśaḥ yaḥ hutabhuj agniḥ
translated: Such is the self-existent fire.

original: asya māhātmyavarṇane purā kila munīnāṃ bhaktānāṃ ca prārthanayā śivena svakīyāyāḥ kālāgnirūdramūrteḥ prākaṭyam asmin sthāne sampāditam ityādi
analyzed: asya māhātmya varṇane purā kila munīnām bhaktānām ca prārthanayā śivena svakīyāyāḥ kālāgni rūdra mūrteḥ prākaṭyam asmin sthāne sampāditam ityādi
translated: In the description of its greatness, it is said that in ancient times, at the request of sages and devotees, Shiva manifested his form of Kalagni Rudra in this place, and so on.

original: likhitam asti /
analyzed: likhitam asti
translated: It is written.

original: atra sarvatra marubhūmir yasyā bhāṣāyāṃ hindīty abhidhāyāṃ karevā kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ ca uḍarnāma vartate /
analyzed: atra sarvatra maru bhūmiḥ yasyāḥ bhāṣāyām hindī iti abhidhāyām karevā kaśmīra bhāṣāyām ca uḍar nāma vartate
translated: Here, in the desert region, the language is called Hindi and in Kashmiri language it is called Udhar.

original: saiva bhūmir anekeṣu sthāneṣu pakvatām āptādādhā ca darīdṛśyate /
analyzed: sā eva bhūmiḥ anekeṣu sthāneṣu pakva tām ca darīdṛśyate
translated: That same land is seen baked and hardened in many places.

original: ato jñāyate 'gnir ayaṃ sarvadā ekasmād eva sthānān na samunmiṣati /
analyzed: atas jñāyate gniḥ ayam sarvadā ekasmāt eva sthānāt na samunmiṣati
translated: Therefore, it is known that this fire does not always arise from the same place.

original: kiṃ tu kadāpy ekatra kadāpy anyatra kadācana tato 'py atra samudayaṃ prāpnoti /
analyzed: kim tu kadāpi ekatra kadāpi anyatra kadācana atra samudayam prāpnoti
translated: But sometimes it appears in one place, sometimes in another, and sometimes it appears in a place even further than that.

original: vadanti ca vṛddhāḥ sarvadaivāyam agnir asmin eva sthāne dvādaśavarṣādhike kāle tato 'py adhike vā prādurbhavati /
analyzed: vadanti ca vṛddhāḥ sarvadā eva ayam agniḥ asmin eva sthāne dvādaśa varṣa adhike kāle adhike vā prādurbhavati
translated: And the elders say that this fire always appears in this very place after twelve years or more.

original: atra yātrikā āgatya śuddhatayā svasvabhāṇḍāni saṃśodhya teṣv eva bhāṇḍeṣu yathāparimāṇaṃ
analyzed: atra yātrikāḥ āgatya śuddha tayā sva sva bhāṇḍāni saṃśodhya teṣu eva bhāṇḍeṣu yathāparimāṇam
translated: And the travelers come and, having purified their own vessels with purity, they put rice and water in those very vessels according to their size,

original: taṇḍulaṃ jalaṃ ca sampātayya kāṣṭhollikhitāyāṃ bhūmau gartākāraṃ kṛtvā tāni bhāṇḍāni
analyzed: taṇḍulam jalam ca sampātayya kāṣṭha ullikhitāyām bhūmau garta ākāram kṛtvā tāni bhāṇḍāni
translated: and having made a pit-like shape on the ground scratched with wood, they place those vessels

original: tasyām eva taptāyāṃ bhūmau muhūrtārdhaṃ sthāpayitvā yāvad gartebhyo 'svasvabhāṇḍāni niṣkāsayanti /
analyzed: tasyām eva taptāyām bhūmau muhūrta ardham sthāpayitvā yāvat gartebhyaḥ sva sva bhāṇḍāni niṣkāsayanti
translated: on that very heated ground for half a moment, and then they take out their own vessels from the pits.

original: tāvad eva tad annaṃ teṣv annabhāṇḍeṣu supakvaṃ pratyuta sarvajanair indhanādipacyamānānnāc chobhanaṃ ca paśyanti /
analyzed: tāvat eva tat annam teṣu anna bhāṇḍeṣu su pakvam pratyuta sarva janaiḥ indhana ādi pacyamāna annāt śobhanam ca paśyanti
translated: And just then that food is well cooked in those food vessels, and moreover all the people see it as more beautiful than the food being cooked with firewood etc.

original: atha te yātrikās tenaivānnena svapitṝṇāṃ piṇḍadānapūrvakaṃ yathāruci yathāvidhi ca śrāddhādi kurvanti /
analyzed: atha te yātrikāḥ tena eva annena sva pitṝṇām piṇḍa dāna pūrvakam yathāruci yathāvidhi ca śrāddha ādi kurvanti
translated: Then those travelers, with that very food, perform the Śrāddha etc. as they like and according to the rules, preceded by offering balls of rice to their ancestors.

original: ye kecana homavidhyabhilāṣiṇas te tu tasyām eva taptāyāṃ bhūmau sarvataḥ śuṣkakāṣṭhāni pātayitvā ghṛtādinā jvālā udbhāvayanti /
analyzed: ye kecana homa vidhi abhilāṣiṇaḥ te tu tasyām eva taptāyām bhūmau sarvatas śuṣka kāṣṭhāni pātayitvā ghṛta ādinā jvālāḥ udbhāvayanti
translated: Those who desire to perform a homa, they, on that very heated ground, having caused dry wood to fall all around, produce flames with ghee etc.

original: tāsv eva jvālāsu svagṛhyoktavidhānena homaṃ kurvanti / ato
analyzed: tāsu eva jvālāsu sva gṛhya ukta vidhānena homam kurvanti
translated: In those very flames, they perform the homa according to the rules stated in their own Grihya texts. Therefore,

original: juhvatāṃ pratigṛhṇāti jvālābhujavanair havir
analyzed: juhvatām pratigṛhṇāti jvālābhu javanaiḥ haviḥ
translated: the one who offers accepts the oblation with the flames as his arms and the forest as his hands,

original: ityādi kalhaṇoktam api saṃgacchate /🔽yataḥ prajvālyamānāgner adhikajvālāvān ayam agnir havir gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: ityādi kalhaṇa uktam api saṃgacchate  yatas prajvālyamāna agneḥ adhika jvālāvān ayam agniḥ haviḥ gṛhṇāti
translated: and so on, stated by Kalhana, is also coherent.🔽Because this fire, which has more flames than the fire being kindled, accepts the oblation.

original: yasmin bhūbhāge 'syāgneḥ prādurbhāvaḥ sa bhūmibhāga atyuṣṇo hastādisparśenāpi lakṣyate /
analyzed: yasmin bhū bhāge sya agneḥ prādurbhāvaḥ sa bhūmi bhāgaḥ ati uṣṇaḥ hasta ādi sparśena api lakṣyate
translated: That part of the ground where this fire appears is extremely hot, even when touched by the hand etc.

original: asya sthānasya svayam iti sarvajagatprasiddhaṃ nāma grāmīṇā nāgarikāś ca vadanti /🔽etat sthānaṃ kramarājyasthe macchepor ityākhye puragaṇe vartate /
analyzed: asya sthānasya svayam iti sarva jagat prasiddham nāma grāmīṇāḥ nāgarikāḥ ca vadanti  etat sthānam krama rājya sthe mad śepoḥ iti ākhye pura gaṇe vartate
translated: The name of this place is well-known to all the world. Villagers and city-dwellers say it.🔽This place is located in the town called Mcchepor, which is in the kingdom of Kram.

original: grāmīṇā etasmin kāle kramarājyapadasya kamrāj asya puragaṇasya tapay macchyapūr iti vadanti /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ etasmin kāle krama rājya padasya kamrāj asya pura gaṇasya tapai iti vadanti
translated: Villagers at this time call the word Kramrajya of this town Tapya Mccheypoor.

original: yasmin grāme 'yam agnis tasya grāmasya nicyahaum iti vadamānā dṛśyante /
analyzed: yasmin grāme yam agniḥ tasya grāmasya iti vadamānāḥ dṛśyante
translated: In which village this fire is seen, the villagers are seen saying, This is our fire.

original: asya nicyahaumgrāmasya nikaṭe 'nyad grāmadvayam apy asti /
analyzed: asya nicya haum grāmasya nikaṭe grāma dvayam api asti
translated: Near this village, there are two other villages.

original: tatraikasya nicyahaumsamīpavartino grāmasya rājypaur iti tasyādhastād vartino 'nyasya grāmasya jacyalaur iti te eva grāmīṇāḥ kathayanti /
analyzed: tatra ekasya nicyahaum samīpa vartinaḥ grāmasya rājypauḥ iti tasya adhastāt vartinaḥ nyasya grāmasya iti te eva grāmīṇāḥ kathayanti
translated: Among them, the villagers of one village near Nicyaum say Rajyapou and the villagers of another village below it say Jacylaur.

original: asmin grāmadvaye rājyapadavācyā janā mlecchā nivasamānā bhavanti /
analyzed: asmin grāma dvaye rājya pada vācyāḥ janāḥ mlecchāḥ nivasamānāḥ bhavanti
translated: In these two villages, people called Rajyapou, who are barbarians, live.

original: ayaṃ nicyahaumgrāmo 'syāgner āścaryībhūtaḥ suyyapurasthānād yasya grāmīṇoccaraṇena sopor iti nāmādhunikaṃ vartate /
analyzed: ayam sya agneḥ āścaryībhūtaḥ suyyapura sthānāt yasya grāmīṇa uccaraṇena sopoḥ iti nāma ādhunikam vartate
translated: This village Nicyaum is a wonder of this fire. The modern name of the village is Sopore, which is pronounced by the villagers.

original: tasmāt sthānād viṃśatikrośadūre pradeśo bhavati /
analyzed: tasmāt sthānāt viṃśati krośa dūre pradeśaḥ bhavati
translated: This place is twenty krośas away from the place of the fire.

original: asmin grāme 'gnisamākalitasthānādau yady api marubhūmir evāsti tathāpi tasya nikaṭa ubhayor eva pārśvayoḥ sasyakṣetreṣu sasyādisamutpattir
analyzed: asmin grāme gni samākalita sthāna ādau yadi api maru bhūmiḥ evā asti tathā api tasya nikaṭe ubhayoḥ eva pārśvayoḥ sasya kṣetreṣu sasya ādi samutpattiḥ
translated: Although in this village and other places included in the fire, there is only a desert land, still near it, in the fields on both sides, the growth of crops and other things

original: bhavaty eva //
analyzed: bhavati eva
translated: happens.

original: Haṃsavāgīśvarī Bheḍā Devīty Aparaparyāyā
translated: Hamsavagishvari Bheda Devi is another name for her.

original: śloka nambar haṃsarūpā sarasvatī /
analyzed: haṃsa rūpā sarasvatī
translated: The goddess Sarasvatī in the form of a swan.

original: devī haṃtyavidyālakṣaṇaṃ tama iti haṃsaḥ paramātmā /
analyzed: devī haṃti avidyā lakṣaṇam tamaḥ iti haṃsaḥ paramātmā
translated: The Supreme Self is called haṃsa because it destroys the darkness characterized by ignorance.

original: tadrūpā tacchaktir iti yāvat /
analyzed: tad rūpā tad śaktiḥ iti yāvat
translated: It is of that form, meaning it is that power.

original: etādṛśī yā sarasvatī vāgadhiṣṭhātrī devī vāgīśvarītyabhidhā eṣā haṃsarūpā sarasvatī /
analyzed: etādṛśī yā sarasvatī vāc adhiṣṭhātrī devī vāgīśvarī iti abhidhā eṣā haṃsa rūpā sarasvatī
translated: Such is the goddess Sarasvatī, the presiding deity of speech, also known as Vāgīśvarī, who is in the form of a swan.

original: bheḍākhyaparvato yo 'tiśayena gacchatyā bhṛṅgītyabhidhāyā nadyā udbhāvanena pavitrībhūtas tasya parvatasya śṛṅge śirasi sarvair dṛśyate /
analyzed: bheḍa ākhya parvataḥ yaḥ u tiśayena gacchatyā bhṛṅgī iti abhidhāyāḥ nadyāḥ udbhāvanena pavitrībhūtaḥ tasya parvatasya śṛṅge śirasi sarvaiḥ dṛśyate
translated: The mountain called Bhairava is greatly traversed by the river called Bhṛṅgī, which sanctifies it by flowing down. It is seen on the peak, the head, of that mountain by all.

original: atra parvatasyopari sara ekam asti /
analyzed: atra parvatasya upari saraḥ ekam asti
translated: Here, on top of the mountain, there is a lake.

original: tad eva saro haṃsavāgīśvaryāḥ sthānatām āptatayā vidyamānaṃ sarvathaiva vartate /
analyzed: tat eva saraḥ haṃsa vāgīśvaryāḥ sthāna tām āpta tayā vidyamānam sarvathā eva vartate
translated: That very lake, having attained the status of the abode of Haṃsavāgīśvarī, exists in every way.

original: bhṛṅgākhyapuragaṇe yā nadī vahati sā bhṛṅgītyabhidhāsya pūrvoktasya parvatasya pāde vahantī bhavati /
analyzed: bhṛṅga ākhya pura gaṇe yā nadī vahati sā bhṛṅgī iti abhidhā asya pūrva uktasya parvatasya pāde vahantī bhavati
translated: The river that flows in the city called Bhṛṅgī becomes the Bhṛṅgī, as mentioned earlier, flowing at the foot of the mountain.

original: grāmīṇās tu bhṛṅg iti puragaṇasya nāma vadamānāḥ /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ tu bhṛṅg iti pura gaṇasya nāma vadamānāḥ
translated: But the villagers say that Bhṛṅgī is the name of the city.

original: tasya bheḍaparvatādhastād vartino grāmasya bheḍaśabdenaiva bhiḍar iti nāmāpi vadanti /
analyzed: tasya bheḍa parvata adhastāt vartinaḥ grāmasya bheḍa śabdena eva bhiḍar iti nāma api vadanti
translated: They also say that the name of the village located at the foot of the Bhairava mountain is Bhairava itself by the word bhairava.

original: ādhunikās tu grāme tasmin vasamānās tasya bheḍaparvatasthasarovarasya kātyāyanītaḍāga iti nāma kecana kathayanti /
analyzed: ādhunikāḥ tu grāme tasmin vasamānāḥ tasya bheḍa parvata stha sarovarasya kātyāyanītaḍāgaḥ iti nāma kecana kathayanti
translated: But the modern inhabitants of that village, some say that the lake on that Bhīḍa mountain is named Kātyāyanī Tīrtha.

original: tatra kātyāyanyā devyā arthāt /
analyzed: tatra kātyāyanyāḥ devyāḥ arthāt
translated: There, for the sake of Goddess Kātyāyanī.

original: asyā eva haṃsavāgīśvaryās taḍāgaḥ sarovaram iti yāvat /
analyzed: asyāḥ eva haṃsa vāgīśvaryāḥ taḍāgaḥ sarovaram iti yāvat
translated: This is the lake, that is, the pond, of this very Haṃsavāgīśvarī.

original: asya kātyāyanītaḍāgasya svabhāṣāyām apabhraṃśadoṣena kāntrāg iti nāma vadamānāś ca bhavanti /
analyzed: asya kātyāyanī taḍāgasya sva bhāṣāyām apabhraṃśa doṣena kāntrāk iti nāma vadamānāḥ ca bhavanti
translated: And they say that the name of this Kātyāyanī Tīrtha is Kāntrāg in the local language due to the fault of a corrupt dialect.

original: tatra kān iti kātyāyanyāḥ trāg taḍāga iti /
analyzed: tatra kān iti kātyāyanyāḥ trāk taḍāga iti
translated: There, kā means Kātyāyanī, and trā means tīrtha.

original: paraṃ tu tasmin parvate sarovaraḥ śirasi parvatasya pāde nady api vahantī vartate / ato
analyzed: param tu tasmin parvate sarovaraḥ śirasi parvatasya pāde nadī api vahantī vartate
translated: But on that mountain, a lake flows at the top of the mountain and rivers flow at the foot. Therefore,

original: devī bheḍagireḥ śṛṅge gaṅgodbhedaśucau svayam /
analyzed: devī bheḍa gireḥ śṛṅge gaṅgā udbheda śucau svayam
translated: the goddess herself on the peak of Bhīḍa mountain, in the pure source of the Ganges,

original: saro 'ntar dṛśyate yatra haṃsarūpā sarasvatīti
analyzed: saraḥ ntar dṛśyate yatra haṃsa rūpā sarasvatī iti
translated: where a lake is seen, in which Sarasvatī in the form of a swan.

original: paṇḍitakalhaṇoktam api saṃgacchate /
analyzed: paṇḍita kalhaṇa uktam api saṃgacchate
translated: This is also consistent with what the scholar Kalhaṇa says.

original: asmin bhiḍarākhyagrāme ekāśilāmayī devīmūrtir jalamadhye 'syā nadyā bhavati /
analyzed: asmin bhiḍara ākhya grāme ekā śilā mayī devī mūrtiḥ jala madhye syāḥ nadyāḥ bhavati
translated: In this village called Bhīḍa, there is an image of the goddess made of stone in the middle of this river.

original: tatratyā grāmīṇās tām eva bheḍadevīṃ manyamānā bheḍadevīśabdenākārayantaḥ pūjayanti /
analyzed: tatratyāḥ grāmīṇāḥ tām eva bheḍadevīm manyamānāḥ bheḍadevī śabdena ākārayantaḥ pūjayanti
translated: The villagers there, considering her to be the same Bhedadevi, invite her with the word Bhedadevi and worship her.🔽In the middle of this group of cities known as Bhrig, the river that flows is called Bhrig by the name Bhrigashbadavya itself.

original: asya puragaṇasya bhṛṅg iti khyātasya madhye yeyaṃ nadī vahaty asyā nadyā bhṛṅgśabdavyapadiṣṭatayaiva bhṛṅgīti nāma yasyāḥ kalhaṇena svapustake
analyzed: asya pura gaṇasya bhṛṅk iti khyātasya madhye yā iyam nadī vahati asyāḥ nadyāḥ bhṛṅga śabda vyapadiṣṭa tayā eva bhṛṅgī iti nāma yasyāḥ kalhaṇena sva pustake
translated: Its name is mentioned by Kalhana in his book

original: gaṅgāśabdena nāmoktam /
analyzed: gaṅgā śabdena nāma uktam
translated: with the word Ganga.

original: anyac ca bheḍādevīśabdenaiva grāmasyāpi bhiḍar iti nāma sampannam /
analyzed: anyat ca bheḍādevī śabdena eva grāmasya api bhiḍar iti nāma sampannam
translated: And the name of the village is also accomplished with the word Bhedadevi itself as Bhidar.

original: vastutas tu parvate bhiḍargrāmasthite yat sarovaraṃ tat haṃsavāgīśvaryāḥ sthānam /
analyzed: vastutas tu parvate bhiḍargrāma sthite yat sarovaram tat haṃsavāgīśvaryāḥ sthānam
translated: But in reality, the lake situated in the Bhidar village on the mountain is the abode of Hansavagishvari.

original: yā parvatasyādhastān nadī bhṛṅgīti vahamānā sāpi parvatād evodgacchati /
analyzed: yā parvatasya adhastāt nadī bhṛṅgī iti vahamānā sā api parvatāt eva udgacchati
translated: The river that flows below the mountain as Bhrig also rises from the mountain itself.

original: tajjalamadhye yā yā śilāmūrtiḥ sā bheḍādevīti grāmīṇamatenāsti /
analyzed: tad jala madhye yā yā śilā mūrtiḥ sā bheḍādevī iti grāmīṇa matena asti
translated: The stone image in the middle of its water exists as Bhedadevi according to the villagers' belief.

original: asya sarovarasya jalaṃ sarvadaivaikākāraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: asya sarovarasya jalam sarvadā eva eka ākāram bhavati
translated: The water of this lake always remains of the same form.

original: na tu kadāpy adhikaṃ kadāpi vā nyūnaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na tu kadāpi adhikam kadāpi vā nyūnam bhavati
translated: It is never more or less at any time.

original: asya jalaṃ atipācakaṃ śītalaṃ madhuraṃ ca bhavati //
analyzed: asya jalam ati pācakam śītalam madhuram ca bhavati
translated: Its water is very digestive, cool and sweet.

original: Nandikṣetram
analyzed: nandikṣetram
translated: The field of Nandini

original: śloka nambara nandikṣetre /
analyzed: śloka nambara nandikṣetre
translated: The verse on the holy place of Nandin.

original: nandayati ānandayati sarvān svabhaktān yaḥ so nandī śivaḥ /
analyzed: nandayati ānandayati sarvān sva bhaktān yaḥ saḥ nandī śivaḥ
translated: He who delights and pleases all his devotees is Nandin, Shiva.

original: tasya yat kṣetraṃ tīrthaṃ tat nandikṣetraṃ /
analyzed: tasya yat kṣetram tīrtham tat nandikṣetram
translated: His holy place, the sacred place, is the Nandin field.

original: atha vā nandīnāmā śivasyānucaro yo gaṇas tatprasādārthaṃ tīrthībhūtaṃ yat sthānaṃ tad eva nandikṣetraṃ /
analyzed: atha vā nandī nāmā śivasya anucaraḥ yaḥ gaṇaḥ tad prasāda artham tīrthībhūtam yat sthānam tat eva nandikṣetram
translated: Or, the place that has become a sacred place for the sake of the attendant named Nandin, who is a leader of Shiva's followers, is the Nandin field.

original: purā kila haramukuṭākhye parvate pārvatyā rahaḥsthitayā tasya parvatasyādhastād dhārapradeśe nandīnāmā svānucaro gaṇamukhyaḥ sthāpitas /
analyzed: purā kila haramukuṭa ākhye parvate pārvatyā rahaḥ sthitayā tasya parvatasya adhastāt dhāra pradeśe nandī nāmā sva anucaraḥ gaṇa mukhyaḥ sthāpitaḥ
translated: It is said that in the past, on the mountain named Haramukuta, by Parvati who was staying in private, her attendant named Nandin, the leader of the followers, was placed in the region below the mountain, in the waterfall area.

original: tasmāt kālād ārabhyaiva tatra nandikṣetraṃ sampannam /
analyzed: tasmāt kālāt ārabhya eva tatra nandikṣetram sampannam
translated: From that time onwards, the Nandin field was established there.

original: tathā ca bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitāyāṃ haramukuṭagaṅgāyātrāmāhātmyavarṇane kadācit pārvatyā śivasya śiraḥsthite kapardākhye jaṭāmukuṭe procchalaṃtī gaṅgā
analyzed: tathā ca bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitāyām haramukuṭa gaṅgā yātrā māhātmya varṇane kadācid pārvatyā śivasya śiraḥ sthite kaparda ākhye jaṭā mukuṭe procchalaṃtī gaṅgā
translated: And in the Bhrigishanshita, in the description of the greatness of the pilgrimage to the Ganges on Haramukuta, it is said that once, by Parvati, the Ganges, which was flowing in the matted hair called Kaparda, which was on Shiva's head,

original: dṛṣṭā /
analyzed: dṛṣṭā
translated: was seen.

original: atha tāṃ svasapatnībhūtāṃ śivasya dayitāṃ dṛṣṭvā sapatnīrṣyayā krodhāndhakuṭiladṛśā ca tayā pārvatyā śivaṃ prati muñcaināṃ matsapatnīm ity
analyzed: atha tām sva sapatnī bhūtām śivasya dayitām dṛṣṭvā sapatnī īrṣyayā krodha andha kuṭila dṛśā ca tayā pārvatyā śivam prati muñca enām mad sapatnīm iti
translated: Then, seeing that beloved of Shiva, who had become her co-wife, out of jealousy towards her co-wife, with eyes crooked and blinded by anger, Parvati said to Shiva, Release this co-wife of mine.

original: atha śivena bahuśo 'nunāthyamānāpi sā pārvatī yady ahaṃ bhavataḥ priyatamā tadāvaśyam eva tyajaitām ityākārakam āgraham eva dhārayām āsa /
analyzed: atha śivena bahuśas nunāthyamānā api sā pārvatī yadi aham bhavataḥ priyatamā tadā avaśyam eva tyaja etām iti ākārakam āgraham eva dhārayām āsa
translated: Then, although entreated by Shiva in many ways, that Parvati held fast to her insistence, saying, If I am your beloved, then you must certainly abandon her.

original: punaś ca pārvatībhaktiparavaśena śivena sā gaṅgā svajaṭāmukuṭād yasmin kāle tyaktā tasminn eva kāle haramukuṭagaṅgā iti nāma tasyā gaṅgāyāḥ
analyzed: punar ca pārvatī bhakti para vaśena śivena sā gaṅgā sva jaṭā mukuṭāt yasmin kāle tyaktā tasmin eva kāle hara mukuṭagaṅgā iti nāma tasyāḥ gaṅgāyāḥ  /
translated: And again, by Shiva, who was completely under the sway of devotion to Parvati, that Ganga was released from his matted hair crown at the very time when she was released, at that very time the name Ganga of Shiva's crown

original: sajjātam /🔽yato harasya śivasya mukuṭād yā gaṅgā nirgatā sā haramukuṭagaṅgeti /
analyzed: sat jātam  yatas harasya śivasya mukuṭāt yā gaṅgā nirgatā sā hara mukuṭa gaṅgā iti
translated: was formed for that Ganga.🔽Because the Ganga that flowed from the crown of Shiva, the auspicious one, is called Ganga of Shiva's crown.

original: atha vā harasya mukuṭād vibhraṣṭā satī bhūmau yato 'ticañcalatayā gatā tato 'pi mukuṭagaṅgeti /
analyzed: atha vā harasya mukuṭāt vibhraṣṭā satī bhūmau ti cañcala tayā gatā mukuṭagaṅgā iti
translated: Or, because she, having fallen from the crown of Shiva, went to the ground with great fickleness, therefore also she is called Ganga of the crown.

original: atha ca śivena pārvatīṃ prati bahusammānapuraḥsaram iti prārthanā kṛtā he devī yaiṣā
analyzed: atha ca śivena pārvatīm prati bahu sammāna puraḥsaram iti prārthanā kṛtā he devī yā eṣā
translated: And then, with great honor towards Parvati, Shiva made this request, O Goddess, this Ganga,

original: gaṅgā mayā tvadājñayā śirastas tyaktā enāṃ punar api dhārayiṣyāmītīdṛśaṃ śivasya🔽vākyaṃ śrutvaivātikrodhayutā devī śivam apahāya svamānadarśanāya svanivasanāspadībhūtaṃ
analyzed: gaṅgā mayā tvad ājñayā śirastaḥ tyaktā enām punar api dhārayiṣyāmi iti īdṛśam śivasya  vākyam śrutvā eva ati krodha yutā devī śivam apahāya sva māna darśanāya sva nivasana āspadībhūtam
translated: Hearing these words of Shiva, the goddess, filled with great anger, left Shiva and went to her own abode, to show her own greatness.🔽 And she said to the gods, I will not hold the Ganga on my head again.

original: haramukuṭākhyaṃ parvatam āruroha /
analyzed: haramukuṭa ākhyam parvatam āruroha
translated: Hearing these words of Shiva, the goddess, filled with great anger, left Shiva and climbed the mountain called Haramukuta, which was the place of her own residence, to show her own dignity.

original: ārohaṇakāle tatparvatapālakaṃ śivasya mukhyānucaraṃ nandinam ityādideśa he nandin atra parvataśikhare rahasyam ekākinī kiṃcit kālaṃ sthāsyāmi
analyzed: ārohaṇa kāle tad parvata pālakam śivasya mukhya anucaram nandinam iti ādideśa he nandin atra parvata śikhare rahasyam ekākinī kiṃcid kālam sthāsyāmi
translated: At the time of climbing, she ordered Nandin, Shiva's chief attendant and the protector of that mountain, O Nandin, alone, I will stay here for some time on the peak of this mountain in secret.

original: ato dvāradeśe 'sya parvatasyādhastāt sthitena bhavatā tathā vidheyaṃ yathā rahaḥsthāyinī māṃ ko 'py anyo na paśyet /
analyzed: atas dvāra deśe parvatasya adhastāt sthitena bhavatā tathā vidheyam yathā rahaḥ sthāyinī mām kaḥ pi anyaḥ na paśyet
translated: Therefore, you, who are standing below this mountain at the gate, should act in such a way that no one else sees me staying in seclusion.

original: punaś ca yadi matsamīpe praviṣṭakāmaḥ kaścanāgacchet asmai kasmā api praveśe 'tra na dātavyaḥ /
analyzed: punar ca yadi mad samīpe praviṣṭa kāmaḥ kaścana āgacchet asmai kasmai api praveśe na dātavyaḥ
translated: Moreover, if someone comes here desiring to enter near me, entry should not be given to him by any means.

original: athaitādṛśīṃ śivasyājñāṃ labdhvā śilāvan niścalatayā yāvat nandī praveṣaṃ vārayamāṇas tiṣṭhati tāvad eva devīṃ sarvatra mṛgayamāṇaḥ śivo 'pi
analyzed: atha etādṛśīm śivasya ājñām labdhvā śilā vat niścala tayā yāvat nandī praveṣam vārayamāṇaḥ tiṣṭhati tāvat eva devīm sarvatra mṛgayamāṇaḥ śivaḥ pi
translated: And having received such an order from Shiva, Nandin remained blocking the entrance with the immobility of a rock. Meanwhile, Shiva, who was searching for the goddess everywhere,

original: haramukuṭasya pādaṃ prāpa /
analyzed: haramukuṭasya pādam prāpa
translated: reached the foot of Hara's crown.

original: tatra śivaḥ śilāvat sthiratayā sthitaṃ nandinaṃ svānucaraṃ dṛṣṭvāpi devīsamīpaṃ praveśakāmo
analyzed: tatra śivaḥ śilā vat sthira tayā sthitam nandinam sva anucaram dṛṣṭvā api devī samīpam praveśa kāmaḥ
translated: There, Shiva, seeing Nandin, his attendant, standing still like a rock, desiring to enter near the Goddess,

original: yāvat parvatārohaṇonmukho babhūva tāvad eva nandinātrārohaṇe rahaḥsthitāyā devyā ājñā na vartate /
analyzed: yāvat parvata ārohaṇa unmukhaḥ babhūva tāvat eva nandinā atra ārohaṇe rahaḥ sthitāyāḥ devyāḥ ājñā na vartate
translated: as he was about to ascend the mountain, Nandin, who was standing in secret, did not obey the command to ascend.

original: ato nārohavyam ity uktvā ruddho niṣiddhaś ca tato yāvac chivaḥ svayaṃ taṃ nandinaṃ
analyzed: atas nā ārohavyam iti uktvā ruddhaḥ niṣiddhaḥ ca tatas yāvat śivaḥ svayam tam nandinam
translated: Therefore, saying You should not ascend, he was stopped and forbidden. Then, as long as Shiva himself

original: bahuśaḥ sambodhayann api svasmād evāgrahāt muhur muhur apracalantaṃ paśyati tāvad🔽evātikrodhakuṭiladṛk sa devas tam iti śaśāpa re mūrkha yasmān māṃ parvatasyāsya parvatasthāyā
analyzed: bahuśas sambodhayan api svasmāt eva agrahāt muhur muhur a pracalantam paśyati tāvat  eva ati krodha kuṭila dṛś sa devaḥ tam iti śaśāpa re mūrkha yasmāt mām parvatasya asya parvata sthāyā
translated: though repeatedly admonishing Nandin, saw him not moving again and again due to his own obstinacy,🔽then indeed, that God, with eyes crooked in extreme anger, cursed him thus: O fool, since you disregard me, the lord of this mountain and of the Goddess

original: devyāś ca svāminam apy avajānāsy ato 'tra parvatasyādhastane bhāge tvaṃ macchāyenātikaṭhinena
analyzed: devyāḥ ca svāminam api avajānāsi atas tra parvatasya adhastane bhāge tvam mad chāyena ati kaṭhinena
translated: standing on the mountain, therefore, by my shadow, which is very hard,

original: jaḍabuddhir jaṭarūpo 'dyaprabhṛti bhaviṣyasi /
analyzed: jaḍa buddhiḥ jaṭa rūpaḥ dya prabhṛti bhaviṣyasi
translated: you will become dull-witted and dull-formed from now on, in the lower part of this mountain.

original: atra saṃskṛtavāṇyāṃ lakāraḍakārayor ekatayā samānārthāt /
analyzed: atra saṃskṛta vāṇyām lakāra ḍakārayoḥ eka tayā samāna arthāt
translated: Here, in Sanskrit, the letters la and ḍa have the same meaning due to their identity.

original: tvaṃ jalarūpo bhaviṣyasi /
analyzed: tvam jala rūpaḥ bhaviṣyasi
translated: You will become water.

original: etac chivamukhapaṅkajāt nirgataṃ śāpavahniṃ śrutvā so nandy api aho śivārdhāyāḥ śivāyā
analyzed: etat śiva mukha paṅkajāt nirgatam śāpa vahnim śrutvā saḥ nandī api aho śiva ardhāyāḥ śivāyāḥ
translated: Hearing this curse-fire that came out of the lotus-face of Śiva, even that Nandin, thinking in his mind,

original: ājñāṃ paripālayate katham ivānena śivenāvicārya vṛthaiva śāpām asyāṃ datta iti svamanasi
analyzed: ājñām paripālayate katham iva anena śivena a vicārya vṛthā eva śāpām asyām datte iti sva manasi
translated: How is it that this Śiva, without any consideration, has thus given this curse to Śivā, who always obeys the command of Śiva?

original: vicārya taṃ svasvāminaṃ pratiśaptuṃ samudyatamanā ity uvāca /
analyzed: vicārya tam sva svāminam pratiśaptum samudyata manāḥ iti uvāca
translated: and with a mind ready to curse his own master, he said this:

original: yasmād bhavatā paravaśasyāpi mamāvicāryaiva śāpo datto 'to bhavān api macchāpenādyaprabhṛti kālarūpo 'traiva majjalāśayasamīpe bhaviṣyasi /
analyzed: yasmāt bhavatā para vaśasya api mama a vicārya eva śāpaḥ bhavān api mad śāpena adya prabhṛti mad jalāśaya samīpe bhaviṣyasi
translated: Since you have given me a curse without any consideration, even though I am under someone else's control, therefore, by my curse, from now on you will become Kāla (Time) in the form of water near this lake of mine.

original: arthāt tvaṃ kālarūpajalavān jalāśayo 'traiva bhaviṣyasi /
analyzed: arthāt tvam kāla rūpa jalavān bhaviṣyasi
translated: In other words, you will become a lake with water in the form of Kāla right here.

original: atas tasmāt kālād ārabhyaiva haramukuṭaparvate 'sya nikaṭavarti jalāśayadvayaṃ śivasya varapradānena pāvakatīrthībhūtaṃ ca sampannam /
analyzed: atas tasmāt kālāt ārabhya eva haramukuṭa parvate nikaṭa varti jalāśaya dvayam śivasya vara pradānena pāvakatīrthībhūtam ca sampannam
translated: Therefore, from that time onwards, the two lakes near this mountain, the crest-jewel of Hara, became holy due to Śiva's granting of boons.

original: tatraikasya nandikṣetraṃ nāma anyasya kālakṣetraṃ nāma vartate /
analyzed: tatra ekasya nandikṣetram nāma anyasya kālakṣetram nāma vartate
translated: One of them is named Nandīkṣetra, the other Kālakṣetra.

original: ādhunike kāle 'pi uktam etaj jalāśayadvayam /
analyzed: ādhunike kāle pi uktam etat jalāśaya dvayam
translated: Even in modern times, this pair of water reservoirs is mentioned.

original: ābhyām eva nāmabhyāṃ nirdiśyamānaṃ śvetajalaṃ kṛṣṇajalaṃ ca yātrikadṛggocaraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ābhyām eva nāmabhyām nirdiśyamānam śveta jalam kṛṣṇa jalam ca yātrika dṛś gocaram bhavati
translated: These two, indicated by their very names, are visible to the eyes of travelers as Śvetajala and Kṛṣṇa-jala.

original: kiṃ tu🔽nandikṣetre surāvāsaprāsāde dyucarārpitāḥ /
analyzed: kim tu  nandikṣetre sura āvāsa prāsāde dyucara arpitāḥ
translated: But🔽In the Nandī region, in the palace of the abode of gods,

original: adyāpi yatra vyajyante pūjācandanabindavaḥ //
analyzed: adyā api yatra vyajyante pūjā candana bindavaḥ
translated: where even today the drops of worship and sandalwood are seen,

original: iti yat paṇḍitakalhaṇena svapustake likhitaṃ /
analyzed: iti yat paṇḍita kalhaṇena sva pustake likhitam
translated: which was written by the scholar Kalhaṇa in his book.

original: tadādhunike kāle prāsādādīnām abhāvena candanabindūnāṃ darśanādi kim api na saṃgacchate /
analyzed: tadā ādhunike kāle prāsāda ādīnām abhāvena candana bindūnām darśana ādi kim api na saṃgacchate
translated: In modern times, with the absence of palaces and so on, the sight of drops of sandalwood and so on does not make sense at all.

original: ato jñāyate puratāne kāle tat sarvam abhaviṣyad eva asyoktajalāśayadvayasya kāśmīrikagrāmīṇabhāṣayā nund kol iti nāmadvayaṃ sarvajanakathyamāṇaṃ
analyzed: atas jñāyate puratāne kāle tat sarvam abhaviṣyat eva asya ukta jalāśaya dvayasya kāśmīrika grāmīṇa bhāṣayā iti nāma dvayam sarva jana kathyamāṇam
translated: Therefore, it is known that in ancient times, all this must have existed, and the pair of names of this mentioned pair of water reservoirs, called Nund and Khol in the Kashmiri rural language,

original: bhavati /🔽etat tīrthadvayaṃ laharābhidhapuragaṇasya paryantabhūmau haramukuṭagaṅgānikaṭe vartate /
analyzed: bhavati  etat tīrtha dvayam lahara abhidha pura gaṇasya paryanta bhūmau haramukuṭa gaṅgā nikaṭe vartate
translated: is told by everyone.🔽This pair of holy places is located near the Haramukuta Gangā near the border area of the town called Lahra.

original: haramukuṭagaṅgāyātrāmārge pūrvam asyaiva tīrthadvayasya darśanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: haramukuṭa gaṅgā yātrā mārge pūrvam asya eva tīrtha dvayasya darśanam bhavati
translated: On the way to Haramukuta Gangā, one first sees this pair of holy places.

original: tadanu mukuṭagaṅgātīraṃ pratiyātrikāḥ samāgacchanti /
analyzed: tadanu mukuṭagaṅgā tīram pratiyātrikāḥ samāgacchanti
translated: Then the pilgrims go to the bank of Mukutaganga.

original: asya puragaṇasya grāmīṇabhāṣāyāṃ lārpargaṇa iti mukuṭagaṅgāyāś ca gaṅgabal iti nāma vartate /
analyzed: asya pura gaṇasya grāmīṇa bhāṣāyām lārpargaṇaḥ iti mukuṭagaṅgāyāḥ ca iti nāma vartate
translated: This group of cities is called Larpur in the local language, and Mukutaganga is called Gangbal.

original: yato bal iti kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ sthānasya nāma bhavati /
analyzed: yatas iti kaśmīra bhāṣāyām sthānasya nāma bhavati
translated: Because bal is the name of a place in the Kashmiri language.

original: ato gaṅgabal iti gaṅgāsthānam iti yāvat /
analyzed: atas iti gaṅgā sthānam iti yāvat
translated: Therefore, Gangbal means the place of the Ganges.

original: asyāṃ haramukuṭagaṅgāyā yātrāyāṃ nunargrāmo yaḥ kaśmīranagarāt saptabhiḥ krośair dūre vartate /
analyzed: asyām haramukuṭagaṅgāyāḥ yātrāyām nunar grāmaḥ yaḥ kaśmīra nagarāt saptabhiḥ krośaiḥ dūre vartate
translated: In this pilgrimage to Haramukutaganga, the village Nunur is located seven krośas from the city of Kashmir.

original: tatra yātrikāḥ pūrvasmin dine samāgatya dvitīyasmin dine karaṅkanadī iti nāmnākhyātāṃ nadīm āśritya tanmārgenaiva rāmarādhan iti grāmaṃ samāgacchanti
analyzed: tatra yātrikāḥ pūrvasmin dine samāgatya dvitīyasmin dine karaṅkanadī iti nāmnā ākhyātām nadīm āśritya tad mārgena eva rāmarādhan iti grāmam samāgacchanti
translated: There, the pilgrims gather on the previous day and on the second day, they reach the village called Ramradhan by following the river called Karanknadī.

original: amuṃ rāmarādhangrāmaṃ yāvat sasyādikṣetrāṇi grāmavartino vṛkṣāś ca sarvathā dṛśyante /
analyzed: amum rāmarādhan grāmam yāvat sasya ādi kṣetrāṇi grāma vartinaḥ vṛkṣāḥ ca sarvathā dṛśyante
translated: Up to this village of Ramradhan, fields of crops and trees of the village are seen everywhere.

original: asmāt sthānād ārabhya parvatā eva sarvatra bhavati /
analyzed: asmāt sthānāt ārabhya parvatāḥ eva sarvatra bhavati
translated: From this place onwards, there are mountains everywhere.

original: tadagragaṇyatāyāṃ bharatābhidho parvato yasya grāmīṇamatena bharuth iti nāmāsti /
analyzed: tad agragaṇya tāyām bharata abhidho parvataḥ yasya grāmīṇa matena bharuth iti nāma asti
translated: At the top of that mountain, there is a mountain called Bharutha, which is considered the first by the villagers.

original: tam āruhya yātrikāṇāṃ gamanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tam āruhya yātrikāṇām gamanam bhavati
translated: Having climbed that, the travelers proceed.

original: asmād eva sthānād ārabhya grāmādikaṃ kim api haramukuṭagaṅgāṃ yāvan na labhyate /
analyzed: asmāt eva sthānāt ārabhya grāma ādikam kim api hara mukuṭa gaṅgām yāvat na labhyate
translated: From this place onwards, nothing like a village etc. is obtained up to the Ganges on the crown of Hara.

original: atratyā vṛkṣā api vanyavṛkṣā eva sarvatra darīdṛśyante /
analyzed: atratyāḥ vṛkṣāḥ api vanya vṛkṣāḥ eva sarvatra darīdṛśyante
translated: The trees here are also seen everywhere as wild trees.

original: bharataparvatād ārabhya haramukuṭaṃ yāvat kvāpi tādṛśā vṛkṣā naiva labhyante yebhyo 'nnapacanādyarthe indhanaṃ gṛhyeta /
analyzed: bharata parvatāt ārabhya haramukuṭam yāvat kvāpi tādṛśāḥ vṛkṣāḥ nā eva labhyante yebhyaḥ anna pacana ādi arthe indhanam gṛhyeta
translated: From the Bharata mountain onwards, nowhere are such trees found up to the crown of Hara, from which fuel could be taken for cooking food etc.

original: kiṃ tu ekaṃ latākṛti kāṣṭhaṃ tādṛśaṃ vartate yad ārdram eva tasminn eva kāle samunmūlitaṃ sad dahati /
analyzed: kim tu ekam latā ākṛti kāṣṭham tādṛśam vartate yat ārdram eva tasmin eva kāle samunmūlitam sat dahati
translated: But there is a kind of creeper wood that burns when uprooted at that very moment while still moist.

original: tasya kāṣṭhasya saṃskṛte vānarendhanam iti nāsti /
analyzed: tasya kāṣṭhasya saṃskṛte vānara indhanam iti na asti
translated: That wood is not considered as monkey fuel.

original: tathā ca kalhaṇaḥ na jvalaty agnisaṃge 'pi nivīryaṃ vānarendhanam /
analyzed: tathā ca kalhaṇaḥ na jvalati agni saṃge vānara indhanam
translated: And thus Kalhana: Even when brought together with fire, the monkey fuel is powerless,

original: ayaṃ kāṣṭhabhedo jvālārahito 'pi pākādikriyaṃ sampādayaty eva asya grāmīṇānāṃ bhāṣaṇe viṭhur vā viṭhar kāṭh nāma bhavatīti //
analyzed: ayam kāṣṭha bhedaḥ jvālā rahitaḥ pāka ādi kriyam sampādayati eva asya grāmīṇānām bhāṣaṇe viṭhuḥ vā nāma bhavati iti
translated: This kind of wood, even without flames, accomplishes actions like cooking. In the speech of the villagers, it is called 'vittha' or 'vittha' in the Kaṭha language.

original: Śāradā Devī
analyzed: śāradā devī
translated: Goddess Sharada

original: śloka nambara śāradā devī tatra śāradāpadaniruktiḥ /
analyzed: śāradā devī tatra śāradā pada niruktiḥ
translated: In the Sharada Tantra, the etymology of the word Sharada is given.

original: śarāṇāṃ bāṇānāṃ samūhaḥ śāraṃ daityāsu jālaṃ dyati khaṇḍayati yā sā śāradā /
analyzed: śarāṇām bāṇānām samūhaḥ śāram daityāsu jālam dyati khaṇḍayati yā sā śāradā
translated: She who destroys the net of demons, the group of arrows, is Sharada.

original: atha vā śāro vāyau sa tu triṣu karbure iti kośamatena /
analyzed: atha vā śāraḥ vāyau sa tu triṣu karbure iti kośa matena
translated: Or, Shar means wind, which is of three types according to the Koshamata.

original: śāraṃ māyārūpaṃ vāyuṃ dyati nāśayati yā sā /
analyzed: śāram māyā rūpam vāyum dyati nāśayati yā sā
translated: She who destroys the illusory wind, Shar, is Sharada.

original: anyac ca /
analyzed: anyat ca
translated: And also,

original: śāraṃ śavalaṃ nānāvidhaṃ śāstrīyaṃ śilpādikaṃ ca jñānaṃ dadāti yā sā /
analyzed: śāram śavalam nānāvidham śāstrīyam śilpa ādikam ca jñānam dadāti yā sā
translated: She who grants the knowledge of Shar, variegated, various scriptures and arts, is Sharada.

original: atha ca śakārasakārayor aikyena śāradā sāradā ca /
analyzed: atha ca śakāra sakārayoḥ aikyena śāradā sāradā ca
translated: And also, by the union of Sha and Sa, Sharada means Sarda.

original: tatra sāraṃ balaṃ yogyaṃ jñānaṃ varādikam uttamaṃ ca yā dadāti sā sāradā /
analyzed: tatra sāram balam yogyam jñānam vara ādikam uttamam ca yā dadāti sā sāra dā
translated: She who grants the essence, strength, ability, knowledge, boon etc., the best, is Sarda.

original: etādṛśīṃ śāradāṃ devīṃ dyotanaśīlāṃ ye paśyaṃti /
analyzed: etādṛśīm śāradām devīm dyotana śīlām ye paśyaṃti
translated: Those who see such a Goddess Sharada, who is of the nature of illumination,

original: arthāt śāradātīrthayātrāṃ ye janāḥ kurvanti /
analyzed: arthāt śāradātīrtha yātrām ye janāḥ kurvanti
translated: in other words, those who undertake the pilgrimage to Sharada,

original: te 'vaśyam eva tasyāḥ prasādena kavisevitā /
analyzed: te vaśyam eva tasyāḥ prasādena kavi sevitā
translated: They certainly attain that language, which is served by poets,

analyzed: kavibhiḥ api sadā pūjyamānā  vaikharī rūpāyā saṃskṛta vāṇī tām vāṇīm prāpnuvanti  śāradāvara prasādāt kavi karma nipuṇāḥ kāvya śakti bhājaḥ kavayaḥ bhavanti  anyat ca  ye tad tīrtha yātrā samudyatāḥ tatra gacchanti te vaśyam madhumatī nāma nadīm api samprāpnuvanti
translated: and is always worshipped by poets.

original: tatra śāradāyāḥ pīṭham āsanam iti vyutpattyā śāradāyā adhiṣṭhānībhūto 'yaṃ deśaḥ śāradāpīṭhapadavācya ity api samīcīnam eva /
analyzed: tatra śāradāyāḥ pīṭham āsanam iti vyutpattyā śāradāyāḥ adhiṣṭhānībhūtaḥ yam deśaḥ śāradāpīṭha pada vācyaḥ iti api samīcīnam eva
translated: There, by the derivation of pīṭha as seat, this place which is the basis of Sharada is rightly called the Sharada Peetha.

original: atra śāradādevīsthāna eko jalāśayaḥ kuṇḍākṛtir asti /
analyzed: atra śāradā devī sthāne ekaḥ jalāśayaḥ kuṇḍa ākṛtiḥ asti
translated: Here, there is a water reservoir in the shape of a pond, which is the abode of Goddess Sharada.

original: yasyopari tādṛśy ekā bṛhacchilā vartate /
analyzed: yasya upari tādṛśī ekā bṛhat śilā vartate
translated: On it, there is a large stone slab of that kind.

original: yayā tat kuṇḍaṃ sarvam antarhitaṃ darīdṛśyamānaṃ sarvathaivāsti /
analyzed: yayā tat kuṇḍam sarvam antarhitam darīdṛśyamānam sarvathā eva asti
translated: By which the entire pond is covered, appearing as if seen through a hole.

original: atra bhādrapadamāsaśuklāṣṭamyāṃ yātrā yātrikaiḥ kriyate /
analyzed: atra bhādrapada māsa śukla aṣṭamyām yātrā yātrikaiḥ kriyate
translated: Here, on the eighth day of the bright fortnight of the month of Bhadra, the pilgrimage is performed by the pilgrims.

original: tathā ca vapanapūrvakaṃ śrāddhahomādikriyākalāpasya niṣpattir apy atra bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca vapana pūrvakam śrāddha homa ādi kriyā kalāpasya niṣpattiḥ api atra bhavati
translated: And thus, the performance of rites like Shraddha, Homa, etc. preceded by shaving, also takes place here.

original: kaśmīranagarād aṣṭabhiḥ prayāṇakaiḥ paḍāv iti khyātaiḥ śāradātīrthaprāptir asti /
analyzed: kaśmīra nagarāt aṣṭabhiḥ prayāṇakaiḥ iti khyātaiḥ śāradātīrtha prāptiḥ asti
translated: From the city of Kashmir, the Sharada Tīrtha is reached by eight stages known as Pada.

original: mārge durgamo 'tiśayena jalaprāyaś ca sarvathā yātrikair ullaṅghyate /
analyzed: mārge jala prāyaḥ ca sarvathā yātrikaiḥ ullaṅghyate
translated: On the way, which is very difficult and mostly watery, is crossed by the pilgrims in every way.

original: etac chāradāsthānaṃ sarvam eva kramarājyamaṇḍalam ullaṅghyāgravartini drauv iti khyāte sthāne vartate /
analyzed: etat śāradā sthānam sarvam eva krama rājya maṇḍalam ullaṅghya agra vartini drauu iti khyāte sthāne vartate
translated: This entire abode of Sharada is situated in the state of Kramraja, beyond the district of Drow.

original: kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ asya śāradāsthānasya śārad iti nāmā kārayaṃti /
analyzed: kaśmīra bhāṣāyām asya śāradā sthānasya śārad iti nāmā kārayanti
translated: In the Kashmiri language, this place Sharada is named Sharad.

original: asya drauvpuragaṇasya karaṇāv mujapharābād gilgith ityādy anekaiḥ kaśmīraparyantabhūsthitapradeśais saha sambandho bhūmair bhavati /
analyzed: asya drauvpura gaṇasya karaṇau mujapharābād gilgith ityādi anekaiḥ kaśmīra paryanta bhū sthita pradeśaiḥ saha sambandhaḥ bhūmaiḥ bhavati
translated: This Draupur region has connections with many areas located up to Kashmir, including Muzaffarabad and Gilgit.

original: etatsthānanivasamānā janā gujjer iti nāmnā khyātā bhavanti /
analyzed: etad sthāna nivasamānāḥ janāḥ gujjeḥ iti nāmnā khyātāḥ bhavanti
translated: The people living in this place are known as Gujjars.

original: ete pañcanadadeśīyabhāṣyamāṇāṃ bhāṣāṃ vadanto darīdṛśyante /
analyzed: ete pañcanada deśīya bhāṣyamāṇām bhāṣām vadantaḥ darīdṛśyante
translated: They are seen speaking a language spoken in the Panjnadi region.

original: etasya sthānasya yātrāyāṃ janānāṃ mārgadvayena gamanaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: etasya sthānasya yātrāyām janānām mārga dvayena gamanam bhavati
translated: In the journey to this place, people go by two routes.

original: Cakradharaḥ
translated: Chakradhara

original: śloka nambara cakrabhṛt /
analyzed: śloka nambara cakrabhṛt
translated: Verse number Chakrabhit.

original: cakraṃ bibharti dhārayati yaḥ sa cakrabhṛt viṣṇuḥ /
analyzed: cakram bibharti dhārayati yaḥ sa cakrabhṛt viṣṇuḥ
translated: He who bears the discus, who holds it, is Chakrabhit, Vishnu.

original: atra bhṛdhātor bhṛṃdhātoś ca dhāranārthe samānatvāc cakrabhṛd eva cakradharaḥ /
analyzed: atra bhṛ dhātoḥ bhṛm dhātoḥ ca dhārana arthe samāna tvāt cakrabhṛt eva cakradharaḥ
translated: Here, Chakrabhit itself is Chakradhara, because the meanings of the roots bhr and bhr are the same in the sense of holding.

original: purā kila devodvejakair nānāvidhair daityais tapobalād āptavaronmattair nānopadravakārakaiś
analyzed: purā kila deva udvejakaiḥ nānāvidhaiḥ daityaiḥ tapaḥ balāt āpta vara unmattaiḥ nānā upadrava kārakaiḥ
translated: In ancient times, it is said, by various kinds of demons who harassed the gods, who became intoxicated by boons obtained through the power of austerities, who caused various kinds of harm,

original: cāta eva yā bhūmer bhārayamāṇair yadā sarvaiva pṛthvī durvyavasthabādhitā tadaiva
analyzed: ca atas eva yāḥ bhūmeḥ bhārayamāṇaiḥ yadā sarvā eva pṛthvī durvyavastha bādhitā tadā eva
translated: And when the earth was completely afflicted by the burden-bearing demons,

original: sā devān samāgatya rudantīty uvāca /
analyzed: sā devān samāgatya rudantī iti uvāca
translated: then that earth, coming to the gods, spoke, weeping.

original: he devā ete varadṛptā daityā māṃ sarvathaiva vādhan kiṃ vidhāsyāmi /
analyzed: he devāḥ ete vara dṛptāḥ daityāḥ mām sarvathā eva vā adhan kim vidhāsyāmi
translated: O gods, these demons, intoxicated with boons, are afflicting me in every way. What shall I do?

original: kathaṃ vā sthāsyāmi /🔽atha te devās tasyā bhūdevyāḥ karuṇaṃ paridevanaṃ śrutvā tāṃ devīṃ viśvāsādhāyibhir
analyzed: katham vā sthāsyāmi  atha te devāḥ tasyāḥ bhūdevyāḥ karuṇam paridevanam śrutvā tām devīm viśvāsa ādhāyibhiḥ
translated: Or how shall I stand?🔽Then those gods, hearing the piteous lamentations of that earth goddess, comforting that goddess with words that inspire confidence,

original: vacanaiḥ parisāntvayitvāsveno 'py udvegaṃ prāptāḥ santo 'titūrṇaṃ sarvajagaccharaṇyaṃ
analyzed: vacanaiḥ parisāntvayitvā a svena u pi udvegam prāptāḥ santaḥ titūrṇam sarva jagat śaraṇyam
translated: and themselves becoming anxious, quickly went for refuge

original: tayā bhūdevyā saha viṣṇuṃ bhagavantaṃ śaranaṃ samājagmuḥ /
analyzed: tayā bhūdevyā saha viṣṇum bhagavantam śaranam samājagmuḥ
translated: to Lord Vishnu, the protector of the entire world, along with that earth goddess.

original: tatra prāptvā te devās taṃ prabhum arthyābhir bahvībhiḥ stutibhir īḍayitvā ca svāgamanābhilāṣam iti procuḥ /
analyzed: tatra prāptvā te devāḥ tam prabhum arthyābhiḥ bahvībhiḥ stutibhiḥ īḍayitvā ca sva āgamana abhilāṣam iti procuḥ
translated: Having arrived there, those gods, having praised that Lord with many meaningful hymns, and having expressed their desire to come, said this:

original: he prabho vayaṃ sarve tathaiṣā pṛthvy api duṣṭadaityair bādhitāḥ santo 'tividvalatayādhunā bhavantaṃ bhagavaṃ taṃ śaraṇaṃ prāptāḥ /
analyzed: he prabho vayam sarve tathā eṣā pṛthvī api duṣṭa daityaiḥ bādhitāḥ bhavantam tam śaraṇam prāptāḥ
translated: O Lord, we all, as well as this earth, being afflicted by wicked demons, now, due to their excessive strength, have come to you, O Blessed One, for refuge.

original: ato yathā vayam anayā devyā saha nirvṛtiṃ labhema tathā daityahananaṃ bhavān vidhātum arhati /
analyzed: atas yathā vayam anayā devyā saha nirvṛtim labhema tathā daitya hananam bhavān vidhātum arhati
translated: Therefore, you should arrange for the slaying of the demons in such a way that we may attain peace along with this goddess.

original: atha devābhimataṃ bhagavān samākarṇya tān devāṃs tāṃ bhūdevīṃ cāgrataḥ kṛtvā śivasya prasādanārthaṃ śivalokaṃ samājagāma /
analyzed: atha deva abhimatam bhagavān samākarṇya tān devān tām bhūdevīm ca agratas kṛtvā śivasya prasādana artham śiva lokam samājagāma
translated: Then, having heard what was desired by the gods, the Lord, placing that Earth Goddess and the gods in front, went to Shiva's world to please Shiva.

original: tatra sa bhagavāṃs taṃ svamūrtim eva śivaṃ tair devais saha stutyādi yathārhapūjābhiḥ
analyzed: tatra sa bhagavān tam sva mūrtim eva śivam taiḥ devaiḥ saha stutya ādi yathārha pūjābhiḥ
translated: There, the Lord, along with those gods, praised that Shiva, his own form, with suitable worship such as praise,

original: samprasādya svakīyāgamanaprayojanaṃ ca śivāya vinivedya tasmād yathāvat santoṣitāt
analyzed: samprasādya svakīya āgamana prayojanam ca śivāya vinivedya tasmāt yathāvat santoṣitāt
translated: and having pleased him, he also informed Shiva about the purpose of his own coming. And from him, who was duly satisfied,

original: sudarśanākhyaṃ cakraṃ daityasamūhanāśakaṃ tadaiva prāptavān /🔽tenaiva cakradhareṇa viṣṇunā tadāprabhṛti sarvatrasthāyidaityahananakarmavidhir ārabdhaḥ /
analyzed: sudarśana ākhyam cakram daitya samūha nāśakam tadā eva prāptavān  tena eva cakradhareṇa viṣṇunā tadā prabhṛti sarvatra sthāyi daitya hanana karma vidhiḥ ārabdhaḥ
translated: he obtained the discus named Sudarshana, which was capable of destroying the groups of demons.🔽By that very Vishnu, the wielder of the discus, the method of slaying demons residing everywhere was started from that time onwards.

original: ata eva kaśmīrasthadaityahananārthaṃ viṣṇunātra vijayeśvaranikaṭavartini pradeśe sthitir āsāditā /
analyzed: atas eva kaśmīra stha daitya hanana artham viṣṇunā atra vijayeśvara nikaṭa vartini pradeśe sthitiḥ āsāditā
translated: For this very reason, Vishnu resorted to residing in this region near Vijaya Ishvara to slay the demons residing in Kashmir.

original: tasyaiva sthānasya pūrvoktacakradharasamāśrayaṇena cakradhara iti nāma sajjātam /
analyzed: tasya eva sthānasya pūrva ukta cakradhara samāśrayaṇena cakradharaḥ iti nāma sat jātam
translated: Due to his dependence on the previously mentioned Cakradhara of that very place, the name Cakradhara was formed.

original: grāmīṇās tu etarhi tasya cakradharasya cakadhar iti nāma kaśṃīrabhāṣāyāṃ kathayanti /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ tu etarhi tasya cakradharasya cakadhar iti nāma kaśṃīra bhāṣāyām kathayanti
translated: But the villagers now call him Cakadhar in the Kashmiri language.

original: tasya ca vijayeśvarasya yannikaṭe ayaṃ cakadhar bhavati tasya vijyabhror iti ādhunikaṃ nāmāsti /
analyzed: tasya ca vijayeśvarasya yat nikaṭe ayam cakadhar bhavati tasya vijyabhroḥ iti ādhunikam nāma asti
translated: And that Vijjabhro, near whom this Cakadhar is, has the modern name Vijjabhro.

original: ayaṃ vijyabhror tathāyaṃ cakadhar api dakṣiṇapārśvapuragaṇe yasyādhunā grāmīṇamatena dacchunporpargaṇa iti nāma bhavati tanmadhya eva vartate
analyzed: ayam tathā ayam cakadhar api dakṣiṇa pārśva pura gaṇe yasya adhunā grāmīṇa matena dacchun porpargaṇaḥ iti nāma bhavati tad madhye eva vartate
translated: This Vijjabhro and this Cakadhar are located in the middle of that very Dakshinaparshupurgana, which now has the name Dachunporpargana in the villagers' opinion.

original: atra lambodarī nāma nadī yasyā adhunā grāmīṇabhāṣāyāṃ lidar iti nāmāsti tasyā eva nadyā vāmapārśvo dakṣiṇaś ca pārśvo yo 'sti /
analyzed: atra lambodarī nāma nadī yasyāḥ adhunā grāmīṇa bhāṣāyām lidar iti nāma asti tasyāḥ eva nadyāḥ vāma pārśvaḥ dakṣiṇaḥ ca pārśvaḥ yaḥ sti
translated: Here is the river named Lambodari, which now has the name Lidar in the villagers' language, and it is on the left and right banks of that very river.

original: tāv eva dakṣiṇapārśvavāmapārśvābhidheyau staḥ /
analyzed: tau eva dakṣiṇa pārśva vāma pārśva abhidheyau staḥ
translated: Those two are called the left and right sides.

original: tatra kaśmīrabhāṣayā vāmapārśvasya khourporpargaṇa dakṣiṇapārśvasya ca dacchunporpargaṇa iti nāmadvayaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tatra kaśmīra bhāṣayā vāma pārśvasya dakṣiṇa pārśvasya ca iti nāma dvayam bhavati
translated: There, in the Kashmiri language, the left side is called Khourporpargana and the right side is called Dachunporpargana.

original: asya cakadharasya samīpe 'nyo grāmo yasya simathan ityabhidhāsti /
analyzed: asya cakadharasya samīpe nyaḥ grāmaḥ yasya simathan iti abhidhā asti
translated: Near this Chakradhara, there is another village named Simathan.

original: so 'pi vartate atra cakadhar adhunālpaḥ parvata iva dṛśyate /
analyzed: saḥ pi vartate atra adhunā alpaḥ parvataḥ iva dṛśyate
translated: It also exists here. Chakradhara is now seen like a small mountain.

original: ayaṃ cakadharākhyaḥ pradeśo vitastānadyā dakṣiṇapārśvasthe taṭe vartate /
analyzed: ayam cakadhara ākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ vitastā nadyāḥ dakṣiṇa pārśva sthe taṭe vartate
