translated: for that long one resides in heaven by the power of time.🔽One who performs śrāddha continuously in the solar field, etc., these places are indeed indicative of the name Leda of this very river.

original: satataṃ śrāddhakṛtsūryakṣetre itīdṝṃśi sthalāni ledarīnāmadyotakāni bhavanty eva asyā eva nadyā dakṣiṇapārśvau yo dvau pradeśo tayor madhye 🔽nady eṣā pravahati /
analyzed: satatam śrāddha kṛt sūrya kṣetre sthalāni ledarī nāma dyotakāni bhavanti eva asyāḥ eva nadyāḥ dakṣiṇa pārśvau yaḥ dvau pradeśau tayoḥ madhye  nadī eṣā pravahati
translated: This river flows between the two regions on its southern bank.

original: grāmīṇās tu ādhunike kāle 'syā lambodarī ledarīnadyā vā lidar āra iti nāma vadanti /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ tu ādhunike kāle syāḥ lambodarī ledarī nadyāḥ vā lidar āre iti nāma vadanti
translated: But the villagers in modern times call this river Lambaodari, Leda, or Lida.

original: tatra yā nadī bṛhatpāṣāṇair madhye pūrṇātivegena calantī dustarā ca bhavet /
analyzed: tatra yā nadī bṛhat pāṣāṇaiḥ madhye pūrṇa ativegena calantī dustarā ca bhavet
translated: There, the river that flows in the middle with large stones, moving with great force and being difficult to cross,

original: tasyāḥ kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ ār iti nāma vadanti /
analyzed: tasyāḥ kaśmīra bhāṣāyām ār iti nāma vadanti
translated: they call it Āri in the Kashmiri language.

original: ayaṃ ca lidarākhyo grāmo 'syā nadyā āspadībhūto yo 'sti tasya grāmīṇabhāṣāyām api lidar ity eva nāma vartate /
analyzed: ayam ca lidara ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ syāḥ nadyāḥ āspadībhūtaḥ sti tasya grāmīṇa bhāṣāyām api lidar iti eva nāma vartate
translated: And this village called Lidar, which is situated on this river, has the same name in the local language as Lidar.

original: ayaṃ grāmo 'sya dakṣiṇapārśvasya dacchunporpargaṇa iti prasiddhasya madhye ledarīnadyās taṭe vartamānaḥ kathyate /
analyzed: ayam grāmaḥ u sya dakṣiṇa pārśvasya iti prasiddhasya madhye ledarī nadyāḥ taṭe vartamānaḥ kathyate
translated: This village is said to be located on the banks of the Lidar river in the middle of the famous Dachunporparga district on its southern side.

original: asyā lambodaryā api grāmīṇamatena lidar ity eva nāma bhavati yasmād gaṇeśabalākhyapradeśād āgacchantī nady eṣāsti /
analyzed: asyāḥ lambodaryāḥ api grāmīṇa matena lidar iti eva nāma bhavati yasmāt gaṇeśabala ākhya pradeśāt āgacchantī nadī eṣā asti
translated: This Lambodarā river also has the same name as Lidar in the local language, as it comes from the region called Gaṇeśabala.

original: tasya kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ gaṇiśabal iti nāma khyātaṃ vartate /
analyzed: tasya kaśmīra bhāṣāyām gaṇiśabal iti nāma khyātam vartate
translated: Its name is known in the Kashmiri language as Gaṇiśabala.

original: tatra gaṇiśasya gaṇeśasya bal sthānam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra gaṇiśasya gaṇeśasya sthānam iti arthaḥ
translated: There, the meaning is the place of Gaṇiśa, Gaṇeśa.

original: ayaṃ gaṇeśabalākhyaḥ pradeśo 'mareśvarayātrāyāṃ prathamaḥ prayāṇakaḥ /
analyzed: ayam gaṇeśabala ākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ mareśvara yātrāyām prathamaḥ prayāṇakaḥ
translated: This region called Gaṇeśabala is the first stage of the pilgrimage to Amareśvara.

original: asmāt tribhiḥ krośair dūrastham adhvānam ullaṅghya pahalgāmākhyaḥ pradeśo dvitīyaḥ prayāṇako 'mareśvarayātrā bhavati yaḥ samāyāti /
analyzed: asmāt tribhiḥ krośaiḥ dūra stham adhvānam ullaṅghya pahalgāma ākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ dvitīyaḥ prayāṇakaḥ mareśvara yātrā bhavati yaḥ samāyāti
translated: Having crossed the distance of three krośas from here, the region called Pahalgāma, the second stage of the pilgrimage to Amareśvara, comes.

original: ayaṃ lidarākhyo grāmo 'nantanāgāt pāścime sthāne dvādaśakrośadūratāyām asti /
analyzed: ayam lidara ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ nantanāgāt pāścime sthāne dvādaśa krośa dūra tāyām asti
translated: This village called Lidara is twelve krośas to the west of Ananta Nāga.

original: atra mandirākhyaṃ devāgāraṃ vinaṣṭaprāyaṃ bṛhatpāṣāṇanirmitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: atra mandira ākhyam devāgāram vinaṣṭa prāyam bṛhat pāṣāṇa nirmitam bhavati
translated: Here there is a large temple made of big stones, mostly destroyed.

original: tat sthānaṃ vikramādityasya navatitame varṣe meghavāhanarājñā tṛtīyataraṅge varṇyamānena nirmitam ityādi /
analyzed: tat sthānam vikramādityasya navatitame varṣe meghavāhana rājñā tṛtīya taraṅge varṇyamānena nirmitam ityādi
translated: That place was built by King Meghavahana in the ninety-first year of Vikramāditya, described in the third wave.

original: mandirasaṃgrahāl labdham atra sthāpitam //
analyzed: mandira saṃgrahāt labdham atra sthāpitam
translated: Obtained from the collection of temples, it is established here.

original: Levāraḥ
analyzed: levāraḥ
translated: Levara

original: ślokasaṃ nambara lavasya caritre levāraṃ /
analyzed: ślokasam nambara lavasya caritre levāram
translated: The number of verses in the character of Lava is Levara.

original: yasya levārasya niruktiḥ /
analyzed: yasya levārasya niruktiḥ
translated: The etymology of Levara is as follows.

original: laḥ śeṣe ca bhaye khyāta iti /
analyzed: laḥ śeṣe ca bhaye khyātaḥ iti
translated: La is known to be for the remainder and fear.

original: tathā vaḥ sāntvane rasevāte ity ekākṣarakośokteś ca levighnāde bhaye vaṃ sāntvanaṃ tatnivāraṇarūpamāsam antāt rāti dadāti yaḥ sa levāraḥ /
analyzed: tathā vaḥ sāntvane iti eka akṣara kośa ukteḥ ca bhaye sāntvanam tad nivāraṇa rūpa māsam antāt rāti dadāti yaḥ sa levāraḥ
translated: And according to the one-syllable dictionary, it is said that Levi is for fear, and Vara is for the removal of that, he who gives that, which is in the form of protection, is Levara.

original: vighnanivārako gaṇeśaḥ /
translated: Gaṇeśa is the remover of obstacles.

original: tathā ca nīlamatavarṇyaṃ mānadevāyatanakīrtanākhye prastāve
analyzed: tathā ca nīla mata varṇyam mānadevāyatana kīrtana ākhye prastāve
translated: And in the context of the description of the temple of Mānadeva called Kirtanā, it is described in the Nīlamātā:

original: bhūrjasvāmī hiḍambeśo levāraḥ śrīvināyakaḥ /
translated: Bhūrjāmī, Hiḍambīśa, Levara, Śrī Vināyaka,

original: utaṅkeśo guhāvāsī bhīmeśaḥ saumukhas tathā //
analyzed: utaṅkeśaḥ guhāvāsī bhīmeśaḥ saumukhaḥ tathā
translated: Utankesha, Guhavasin, Bhemesha, Saumukha,

original: bhadreśvaro mahāsyaś ca mahāśanagaveṣaṇau /
analyzed: bhadreśvaraḥ mahāsyaḥ ca mahāśana gaveṣaṇau
translated: Bhadrashvara, Mahashya, Mahashana, and Gaveshana,

original: paulastyo girivāsī ca jayeśvaramaheśvarau //
analyzed: paulastyaḥ girivāsī ca jayeśvara maheśvarau
translated: Paulashtya, Girivasin, Jayeshvara, and Mahesvara,

original: ekaikam ebhyo dṛṣṭvā tu gaṇeśaṃ susamāhitaḥ /
analyzed: ekaikam ebhyaḥ dṛṣṭvā tu gaṇeśam su samāhitaḥ
translated: Seeing each of these Ganeshas with great concentration,

original: kāryasiddhim avāpnoti puṇyaṃ phalam upāśnute //
analyzed: kārya siddhim avāpnoti puṇyam phalam upāśnute
translated: One attains success in one's endeavors and enjoys the fruits of merit.

original: ity ādau /
analyzed: iti ādau
translated: Thus it is said.

original: asya levārākhyagaṇeśasya kaśmīrasthagaṇeśamūrtiṣu varṇyamānatvaṃ sphuṭatayā bhavati /
analyzed: asya levāra ākhya gaṇeśasya kaśmīra stha gaṇeśa mūrtiṣu varṇyamāna tvam sphuṭa tayā bhavati
translated: This Ganesha named Levara is clearly described among the Ganesha images in Kashmir.

original: eṣā gaṇeśamūrtiḥ pūrvoktaledarīnadyā vāmapārśve yo 'dhunā grāmīṇabhāṣāvyavahṛtau khourporpargaṇa iti nāma dhārayati tasminn eva pradeśe sarvaviditā 🔽vartate /🔽asya gaṇeśasya nāmnevāyaṃ gaṇeśamūrtyāśrayavān grāmo levar iti nāmnaiva prakhyāta / / /ḥ sampannaḥ vartate /
analyzed: eṣā gaṇeśa mūrtiḥ pūrva ukta ledarī nadyāḥ vāma pārśve yaḥ dhunā grāmīṇa bhāṣā vyavahṛtau iti nāma dhārayati tasmin eva pradeśe sarva viditā  / vartate  asya gaṇeśasya nāmnā iva ayam gaṇeśa mūrti āśrayavān grāmaḥ levar iti nāmnā eva prakhyātaḥ sampannaḥ vartate
translated: This Ganesha image is on the left bank of the Ledari river mentioned earlier, in the very same region that is now known in the local language as Khourparga Ganesha, and is well-known to all.🔽This village that is the abode of this Ganesha image is well-known by the very name of Levara.

original: cāyaṃ grāmo 'smin puragaṇe levarśabdābhidheyo grāmīṇaiḥ kathyamānaḥ /
analyzed: ca ayam grāmaḥ u smin pura gaṇe levar śabda abhidheyaḥ grāmīṇaiḥ kathyamānaḥ
translated: And this village is spoken of by the villagers as being in this city region, designated by the word Levara.

original: asya grāmasya nikaṭe 'nyo 'pi grāmaḥ sarvaviditaḥ sīr ityākhyo bhavati /
analyzed: asya grāmasya nikaṭe grāmaḥ sarva viditaḥ sīḥ iti ākhyaḥ bhavati
translated: Near this village, there is another well-known village called Sīr.

original: tasyaivaṃ kiṃcid dūratāyām ayaṃ grāmaḥ pūrvam eva levārākhyasya gaṇapater āśrayatayaiva tādṛśanāmayuta eva tena varṇyamānena lavarājñā agrahāratvavyapadeśavān
analyzed: tasya evam kiṃcid dūra tāyām ayam grāmaḥ pūrvam eva levāra ākhyasya gaṇapateḥ āśraya tayā eva tādṛśa nāma yutaḥ eva tena varṇyamānena lava rājñā agrahāra tva vyapadeśavān
translated: When it is a little far from there, this village was first given as a grant to the lord of the Gaṇas named Levara by that king Levara, who was described as such.

original: samapādi /
analyzed: samapādi
translated: He obtained it.

original: ata eva paṇḍitakalhaṇenāpi prathame taraṅge
analyzed: atas eva paṇḍita kalhaṇena api prathame taraṅge
translated: For this very reason, it was also said by the learned Kalhaṇa in the first wave:

original: dattvāgrahāraṃ ledaryāṃ levāraṃ dvijaparṣade /
analyzed: dattvā agrahāram ledaryām levāram dvija parṣade
translated: Having given a grant to Leḍarī, Levara to the assembly of Brāhmaṇas,

original: sa dyāmanindyaśauryaśrīr āruroha mahābhujaḥ //
analyzed: sa dyām anindya śaurya śrīḥ āruroha mahā bhujaḥ
translated: That king of mighty arms, of irreproachable valor and glory, ascended to heaven.

original: ity ādyuktam /
analyzed: iti ādi uktam
translated: Thus it is said.

original: anayaiva vidhayā yo 'yaṃ grāmo levārākhyaḥ pūrvam eva babhūva /
analyzed: anayā eva vidhayā yaḥ yam grāmaḥ levāra ākhyaḥ pūrvam eva babhūva
translated: In the same way, this village named Levara existed before.

original: sa eva rājñāpi brāhmaṇebhyo 'grahārasamarpaṇakāle ca pūrvaprakhyātanāmnaiva saṃsthāpitaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ eva rājñā api brāhmaṇebhyaḥ grahāra samarpaṇa kāle ca pūrva prakhyāta nāmnā eva saṃsthāpitaḥ
translated: It was also established by the king himself with the same well-known name when he was giving it as a grant to the Brāhmaṇas.

original: dānavelāyām api gaṇeśamūrtyāśrayatvavyapadiṣṭaṃ levārākhyaṃ nāmaiva rājñāpy asyāpi tamasyeti budhyate /
analyzed: dāna velāyām api gaṇeśa mūrti āśraya tva vyapadiṣṭam levāra ākhyam nāma eva rājñā api asya api tamasya iti budhyate
translated: Even at the time of the grant, the king understood that this village named Levara, which was indicated as the abode of Gaṇeśa, was the same as Tamasa.

original: kathayanti ca tatratyāḥ /
analyzed: kathayanti ca tatratyāḥ
translated: And those who live there say:

original: asmin grāme eko mahāvṛkṣo yaṃ vṛkṣaṃ kāśmīrikā braṇ iti śabdenākārayanti /
analyzed: asmin grāme ekaḥ mahā vṛkṣaḥ yam vṛkṣam kāśmīrikāḥ braṭ iti śabdena akārayanti
translated: In this village, there is a great tree which the Kashmiris call by the word 'bran'.

original: tenāpy upalakṣaṇībhūto bhavati sa eva vṛkṣo 'py asyoktagaṇeśasyādhiṣṭhānībhūto bhavati /
analyzed: tena api upalakṣaṇībhūtaḥ bhavati saḥ eva vṛkṣaḥ u pi asya ukta gaṇeśasya adhiṣṭhānībhūtaḥ bhavati
translated: That tree also becomes the object of designation, and that very tree becomes the abode of that aforementioned Ganesha.

original: yato bahavo vṛkṣāḥ anena braṇvṛkṣena kathyamānāḥ kaśmīradeśe devatāmūrtīnām adhiṣṭhānībhūtāḥ sarvato darīdṛśyante iti śam //
analyzed: yatas bahavaḥ vṛkṣāḥ anena braṇ vṛkṣena kathyamānāḥ kaśmīra deśe devatā mūrtīnām adhiṣṭhānībhūtāḥ sarvatas darīdṛśyante iti śam
translated: Because many trees are described by this bran tree, and are seen everywhere in the Kashmir region as the abodes of the images of deities. Thus, peace!

original: Kuruhāraḥ
analyzed: kuruhāraḥ
translated: The Kuru Necklace

original: ślokasaṃ nambara kuśasya rājṇo varṇane kuruhār /
analyzed: ślokasam nambara kuśasya rājṇaḥ varṇane kuru hār
translated: The description of the necklace of the Kuru country, consisting of a hundred verses, is the Kuru necklace.

original: asya nirvacanam /
analyzed: asya nirvacanam
translated: Its etymology is given.

original: kaś cātmāpi samākhyātaḥ kaḥ pradeśa udāhṛta iti kośamatena /🔽kair nānāvidhajalasthalādipradeśaiḥ urur mahān ata eva hāro manoharaś ca yaḥ sa kuruhāraḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ ca ātmā api samākhyātaḥ kaḥ pradeśaḥ udāhṛtaḥ iti kośa matena  kaiḥ nānāvidha jala sthala ādi pradeśaiḥ uruḥ mahān atas eva hāraḥ manoharaḥ ca yaḥ sa kuruhāraḥ
translated: And the self is also mentioned, and the region is stated according to the Kosha view.🔽It is vast and great due to its various regions of water, land, etc., and therefore it is the Kuru necklace, which delights the mind.

original: nānāvidhapradeśamattayāntyā ledarīnadyā hāro muktāhāra iva yaḥ so 'pi kuruhāraḥ /
analyzed: nānāvidha pradeśa mattayā antyā ledarī nadyā hāraḥ muktā hāraḥ iva yaḥ saḥ pi kuruhāraḥ
translated: It is also the Kuru necklace, which is like a pearl necklace with the final Ledari river, which is full of various regions.

original: atha vā kurunāmakair janapadair etaddeśanivāsibhir hriyate yo 'grahāratayāgra eva so 'pi kuruhāraḥ /
analyzed: atha vā kuru nāmakaiḥ janapadaiḥ etad deśa nivāsibhiḥ hriyate yaḥ grahāra tayā agre eva saḥ kuruhāraḥ
translated: Or, it is also the Kuru necklace, which is taken by the people of the country named Kuru as a grant of land, as if it were a necklace.

original: pūrvam etan nāmni pradeśe kuru ityākhyāṃ bibhrāṇā vāstavyā babhūvuḥ /
analyzed: pūrvam etat nāmni pradeśe kuru iti ākhyām bibhrāṇāḥ vāstavyāḥ babhūvuḥ
translated: In ancient times, the inhabitants of this region bore the name Kuru.

original: tair yato 'sya grāmasya sasyādisampattir ādāv eva hriyate smāto 'pi kuruhāraḥ /
analyzed: taiḥ yatas sya grāmasya sasya ādi sampattiḥ ādau eva hriyate sma atas pi kuruhāraḥ
translated: Since they first took away the abundance of crops and other riches of this village, it is also called Kuruhara.

original: ata eva paṇḍitakalhaṇenāpi
analyzed: atas eva paṇḍita kalhaṇena api
translated: For this very reason, the learned Kalhana also

original: kuruhārāgrahārasya dātābhūt tadanantaram /
analyzed: kuruhāra agrahārasya dātā abhūt tad anantaram
translated: said, After that, he became the giver of the Kuruhara agraharam.

original: iti kathanavaśād asya kuruhārāgrahāra iti samastaṃ nāma likhitam /
analyzed: iti kathana vaśāt asya kuruhārāgrahāraḥ iti samastam nāma likhitam
translated: Due to this statement, its complete name is written as Kuruhara agraharam.

original: yataḥ sarveṣām evāgrahārāṇāṃ sasyādisampatte rājagrāhya bhāgāt pūrvam eva nayanenāgrahāratvena vyapadeśaḥ /🔽asya kuruhārapradeśasyādhunike kāle sarve grāmīṇāḥ svabhāṣāyāṃ kular iti sarvakāśmīrakaviditaṃ nāma kathayanti /
analyzed: yatas sarveṣām eva agrahārāṇām sasya ādi sampatte rāja grāhya bhāgāt pūrvam eva nayanena agrahāra tvena vyapadeśaḥ  asya kuruhāra pradeśasya ādhunike kāle sarve grāmīṇāḥ sva bhāṣāyām iti sarva kāśmīraka viditam nāma kathayanti
translated: Because all agraharas are designated as agraharas by the act of taking away the abundance of crops and other riches before the king's share.🔽In modern times, all the villagers of this Kuruhara region call it by the name Kulra in their own language, which is well-known to all Kashmiris.

original: ayaṃ kuruhāra vā kularākhyo grāmo dakṣiṇapārśve dacchunporpargaṇa ityākhyayā janaiḥ sarvataḥ kathyamāno vartate /
analyzed: ayam kuruhāra vā kulara ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ dakṣiṇa pārśve iti ākhyayā janaiḥ sarvatas kathyamānaḥ vartate
translated: This village called Kuruhara or Kulra is situated on the southern side, being called by the name Dachunporpargan by the people all around.

original: asya kular grāmasya nikaṭe anyo 'pi grāmo 'tiprasiddho bhavati 'yam adhunā salar ityākhyayā janāḥ samastapuragaṇaprasiddhaṃ nāma vadanto dṛśyante
analyzed: asya grāmasya nikaṭe anyaḥ pi grāmaḥ ti prasiddhaḥ bhavati yam adhunā iti ākhyayā janāḥ samasta pura gaṇa prasiddham nāma vadantaḥ dṛśyante
translated: Near this village of Kulur, there is another village which is very famous, which is now seen by people using the name Salar, known to all the city folk.

original: ubhāv evaitau kularsalar ityākhyau grāmau yātrikāṇām amareśvarayātrāyāṃ madhye mārgaṃ dṛggocaram āgacchataḥ /
analyzed: ubhau eva etau kularsalar iti ākhyau grāmau yātrikāṇām amara īśvara yātrāyām madhye mārgam dṛś gocaram āgacchataḥ
translated: Both these villages named Kulur and Salar come within sight on the way in the middle for the travelers on the Amarā-Śiva pilgrimage.

original: pratyutobhayor eva tīrthibhūtayor grāmayos teṣāṃ snānapūjādikartavyatāpy amareśvarayātrām atāśrayaṇenāsti /
analyzed: pratyuta ubhayoḥ eva tīrthi bhūtayoḥ grāmayoḥ teṣām snāna pūjā ādi kartavya tā api amara īśvara yātrām atas āśrayaṇena asti
translated: Moreover, for both these pilgrim villages, there is the duty of bathing, worship, etc., without resorting to the Amarā-Śiva pilgrimage.

original: asyaiva kuruhārapradeśasyāpabhraṃśavaśāc cirakālāgatāt kular iti nāma sajjātam /
analyzed: asya eva kuruhāra pradeśasya apabhraṃśa vaśāt cira kāla āgatāt kular iti nāma sat jātam
translated: Due to the corruption of this very Kuru-hāra region, the name Kulur has come about after a long time.

original: kecit tu asya kuruhārākhyasya pradeśasya kāṭhus iti nāma kathayanti /
analyzed: kecid tu asya kuruhāra ākhyasya pradeśasya kāṭhus iti nāma kathayanti
translated: But some people call this region by the name Kāṭus.

original: tanmatena kāṭhus iti kular ity asyaiva cirakālāgatam apabhraṃśadoṣotthaṃ nāma bhavati /
analyzed: tad matena iti kular iti asya eva cira kāla āgatam apabhraṃśa doṣa uttham nāma bhavati
translated: According to that view, Kāṭus is the long-standing corrupted name of this very Kulur.

original: vastutas tu kuruhāraśabdasya kāṭhusśabdena tādṛśyaṃ sāmyam uccaraṇena jñāyate yādṛśaṃ tasya kularśabde na bhāti /
analyzed: vastutas tu kuruhāra śabdasya kāṭhus śabdena tādṛśyam sāmyam uccaraṇena jñāyate yādṛśam tasya na bhāti
translated: But in reality, the similarity of the word Kuruhaṭa with the word Kaṭu is known by pronunciation, not as it appears with the word Kulaṭa.

original: atas samīcīnaṃ kular ity evāsya kuruhārasyāpabhraṃśadoṣotthaṃ nāma paraṃ tu ayaṃ kāṭhusākhyo grāmo 'py asminn eva dacchunporpargaṇe 'mareśvarayātrāmārgamadhye 🔽bhavati /
analyzed: atas samīcīnam iti eva asya kuruhārasya apabhraṃśa doṣa uttham nāma param tu ayam kāṭhusa ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ api asmin eva mara īśvara yātrā mārga madhye  bhavati
translated: Therefore, the correct name of this Kuruhaṭa is Kulaṭa. But this village called Kaṭu is also in this very Daśapura-gṛha, in the middle of the path of the pilgrimage of Amareśvara.

original: yātrikāṇāṃ tatrāpy uktagrāmadvayaravasnānādikartavyatā bhavati /
analyzed: yātrikāṇām tatra api ukta grāma dvaya rava snāna ādi kartavya tā bhavati
translated: Pilgrims also have the duty of bathing in the two mentioned villages there.

original: ataḥ salarkularākhyagrāmadvayanaikaṭyabhāg ayaṃ tṛtīyo grāmaḥ kuruhār iti vyapadiṣṭo bhrameṇaivāsti //
analyzed: atas salarkulara ākhya grāma dvaya naikaṭya bhāj ayam tṛtīyaḥ grāmaḥ kuruhār iti vyapadiṣṭaḥ bhrameṇa evā asti
translated: Therefore, this third village, which is close to the two villages called Sala and Kulaṭa, is designated as Kuruhaṭa, and exists only through delusion.

original: Khāgi
analyzed: kha a gi
translated: Khagi

original: ślokasaṃ namba khagendrasya rājyavarṇane khāginirvacanam /
analyzed: namba khaga indrasya rājya varṇane khāgi nirvacanam
translated: The definition of Khagi in the description of the kingdom of Khagendra.

original: atra khe ākāśe gacchatīti khagaḥ /
analyzed: atra khe ākāśe gacchati iti khagaḥ
translated: Here, one who goes in the sky is a bird.

original: khaga e / / /gaḥ /
analyzed: kha gaḥ egaḥ
translated: A bird is a bird.

original: atha vā khe ākāśe āsamantād gacchatīti khāgaḥ /
analyzed: atha vā khe ākāśe ā samantāt gacchati iti khāgaḥ
translated: Or, one who goes everywhere in the sky is a bird.

original: garuḍābhidho viṣṇor yānaṃ pakṣī khāgo vidyate yasya saḥ khāgī viṣṇuḥ /
analyzed: garuḍa abhidhaḥ viṣṇoḥ yānam pakṣī khāgaḥ vidyate yasya saḥ khāgī viṣṇuḥ
translated: Vishnu, who is called Garuda, has a bird as his vehicle. He who has a bird is Khagi, Vishnu.

original: ayaṃ pradeśo viṣṇor murter adhiṣṭhanitvaṃ yato bibhārti /
analyzed: ayam pradeśaḥ viṣṇoḥ murteḥ adhiṣṭhani tvam yatas bibhārti
translated: This place is known as the abode of Vishnu's image,

original: ata eva khāgīti tasya viṣṇor eva nāmnā prakhyātiṃ samāgataḥ /
analyzed: atas eva khāgī iti tasya viṣṇoḥ eva nāmnā prakhyātim samāgataḥ
translated: and therefore it has become famous by the name of that Vishnu himself.

original: anyac ca etat pradeśanikaṭavartino garuḍanāmāṅkitasya garuḍāśramābhidhasya sthānasya
analyzed: anyat ca etat pradeśa nikaṭa vartinaḥ garuḍa nāma aṅkitasya garuḍa āśrama abhidhasya sthānasya
translated: Moreover, this place is near a place named Garuda Ashrama, marked with the name Garuda,

original: sāmīpyena garuḍasya sadaiva viṣṇor vāhanatvena ca tatnāmnāpy ayaṃ prathāṃ prāpto
analyzed: sāmīpyena garuḍasya sadā eva viṣṇoḥ vāhana tvena ca ayam prathām
translated: and because Garuda is always Vishnu's vehicle, it has also become known by that name.

original: 'taḥ khāgīti nāmāsya pradeśasya yuktatamaṃ bhāti /
analyzed: taḥ khāgī iti nāma asya pradeśasya yuktatamam bhāti
translated: Therefore, the name Khaag is the most appropriate for this place.

original: asmin khāgīti prathite grāme viṣṇoḥ pratimāyā adhiṣṭhānaṃ nārāyaṇakuṇḍeti sarvajanavidito madhyam aparīmāṇa eko jalāśayo bhavati /
analyzed: asmin khāgī iti prathite grāme viṣṇoḥ pratimāyāḥ adhiṣṭhānam nārāyaṇakuṇḍa iti sarva jana viditaḥ madhyam aparīmāṇaḥ ekaḥ jalāśayaḥ bhavati
translated: In this famous village of Khaag, there is a well-known central water reservoir named Narayana Kund, which is the abode of Vishnu's image.

original: kāśmīrakās tu tasya nārāyaṇakuṇḍasyādhunike kāle svabhāṣayā nārāṇ nāg iti prathitaṃ nāma kathayanti /
analyzed: kāśmīrakāḥ tu tasya nārāyaṇakuṇḍasya ādhunike kāle sva bhāṣayā nārāj nāc iti prathitam nāma kathayanti
translated: But the Kashmiris say that the modern name of that Narayana Kund is known in their language as Narang Nag.

original: punaś ca yasyoktagaruḍāśramasya naikaṭyasattayāpy ayaṃ pradeśa enāṃ khāg ityākhyāṃ dhārayati /
analyzed: punar ca yasya ukta garuḍa āśramasya naikaṭya sattayā api ayam pradeśaḥ enām khāc iti ākhyām dhārayati
translated: And again, this place bears the name Khaag because of its proximity to that Garuda Ashrama mentioned above.

original: tasya garuḍāśramasyāpi yathā khāgīti pradeśasyāpabhraṃśadoṣotthaṃ khāg iti nāmadheyaṃ samudbhūtaṃ tathaiva tena doṣeṇa gaṇiśram iti nāma grāmīṇāḥ
analyzed: tasya garuḍa āśramasya api yathā khāgī iti pradeśasya apabhraṃśa doṣa uttham khāk iti nāmadheyam samudbhūtam tathā eva tena doṣeṇa gaṇiśram iti nāma grāmīṇāḥ
translated: Just as the name Khaag of the region of Garudasrama originated due to the fault of a corrupted pronunciation, in the same way, due to that fault, the villagers call it Ganishram.

original: sarvato bruvāṇā bhavanti /
analyzed: sarvatas bruvāṇāḥ bhavanti
translated: They say it from all sides.

original: ato varṇitam etat sthānadvayaṃ bahurūpa ityākhye puragaṇe tīrthībhūtam adhunāpy asti /
analyzed: atas varṇitam etat sthāna dvayam bahurūpaḥ iti ākhye pura gaṇe tīrthībhūtam adhunā api asti
translated: Therefore, these two places are described as existing even now as holy places in the city called Bahurupa.

original: asyāpi bahurūpapuragaṇasya grāmīṇaiḥ prakhyāpitaṃ bīrūpargaṇa iti nāmādhunike kāle saṃlagnam /
analyzed: asya api bahurūpa pura gaṇasya grāmīṇaiḥ prakhyāpitam bīrūpargaṇaḥ iti nāma adhunike kāle saṃlagnam
translated: This Bahurupa city is also known by the villagers as Virupa, a name that has come to be associated in modern times.

original: asmin bahurūpākhye puragaṇe nārāyaṇakuṇḍādīnām etādṛśānāṃ tīrthānāṃ sadbhāvenaivātimāhātmyavattvaṃ sarvatra prasiddham asti /
analyzed: asmin bahurūpa ākhye pura gaṇe nārāyaṇa kuṇḍa ādīnām etādṛśānām tīrthānām sadbhāvena eva ati māhātmyavat tvam sarvatra prasiddham asti
translated: The great importance of this Bahurupa city is well-known everywhere due to the presence of holy places like Narayana Kund.

original: tathā ca nīlamate bahurūpe naraḥ snātvā viṣṇuloke mahīyate /
analyzed: tathā ca nīlamate bahurūpe naraḥ snātvā viṣṇu loke mahīyate
translated: And thus in the Nilamata, it is said: A man who bathes in Bahurupa goes to Vishnu's world and is honored there.

original: bahurūpe ca kathitaṃ phalam etan narottama //
analyzed: bahurūpe ca kathitam phalam etat narottama
translated: And in Bahurupa, this fruit is told for the best of men.

original: ityādi /
analyzed: ityādi
translated: And so on.

original: ayaṃ nārāyaṇ nāgākhyo jalāśayaś catuṣkoṇākāro 'tiśayena śītalasparśajalavās tathāmadhurāsvādaś ca bhavati /
analyzed: ayam nārāyan nāga ākhyaḥ jalāśayaḥ catuṣkoṇa ākāraḥ tiśayena śītala sparśa jala vāḥ tathā madhura āsvādaḥ ca bhavati
translated: This lake called Narayana Naga is square-shaped, has extremely cool water, and has a sweet taste.

original: asya jalāśayasya mukhaṃ bṛhatpāṣāṇaiś catasṛṣv eva dikṣu ghaṭitam asti /
analyzed: asya jalāśayasya mukham bṛhat pāṣāṇaiḥ catasṛṣu eva dikṣu ghaṭitam asti
translated: The mouth of this lake is closed on all four sides with large stones.

original: ayaṃ pradeśaḥ svalpair marubhūmisadṛśaiḥ parvataiḥ prāptabhūmau parivṛto dṛśyate /
analyzed: ayam pradeśaḥ su alpaiḥ maru bhūmi sadṛśaiḥ parvataiḥ prāpta bhūmau parivṛtaḥ dṛśyate
translated: This place is seen surrounded by small mountains resembling desert lands on the ground.

original: ayam api khāgiti prācīnam eva nāma bibhrāṇo rājñāgrahāreti vyapadeśayutaḥ samapādita ity anumīyate //
analyzed: ayam api khāc iti prācīnam eva nāma bibhrāṇaḥ rājñā agrahāra iti vyapadeśa yutaḥ samapāditaḥ iti anumīyate
translated: This one also, bearing the ancient name of Khaga, is inferred to have been given the designation of Rajnagara.

original: Khonamuṣaḥ
analyzed: kha una muṣaḥ
translated: Khaonamusha

original: ślokasaṃ namba khagendrasya varṇane khonamuṣaḥ /
analyzed: ślokasam namba khaga indrasya varṇane
translated: In the description of the king of birds, Khagesa, Khaonamusha is mentioned.

original: asya niruktiḥ /
analyzed: asya niruktiḥ
translated: Here is the etymology.

original: kham indriyaṃ samākhyātaṃ kham ākāśe nigadyate /
analyzed: kham indriyam samākhyātam kham ākāśe nigadyate
translated: Space is said to be the sense organ, space is said to be in the sky.

original: tathāṃśuke ca khaṃ proktaṃ khaṃ śūnyaṃ ca prakīrtitaṃ iti kośamatena /🔽khair vastrair ūno rahito digambaraḥ śiva iti yāvat /
analyzed: tathā aṃśuke ca kham proktam kham śūnyam ca prakīrtitam iti kośa matena  khaiḥ vastraiḥ ūnaḥ rahitaḥ digambaraḥ śivaḥ iti yāvat
translated: And in the same way, space is said to be in the cloth, and space is declared to be empty, according to the Koshamata.🔽He who is devoid of clothes, devoid of garments, is a naked ascetic, up to this much.

original: taṃ khonaṃ śivaṃ parvatasthaguhāyāṃ muṣṇāti corayati yaḥ saḥ khonamuṣaḥ /
analyzed: tam khonam śivam parvata stha guhāyām muṣṇāti corayati yaḥ saḥ khona muṣaḥ
translated: He who steals, robs that Khaga, Shiva, who is in the cave on the mountain, he is Khaonamusha.

original: atha vā khena śūnyo nono rahitaḥ paripūrṇaḥ pūrṇimācandras taṃ svakīyayā śītalayā manohāriṇyā ca śobhayā muṣṇāti yaḥ so 'pi khonamuṣaḥ /
analyzed: atha vā khena śūnyaḥ na ūnaḥ rahitaḥ paripūrṇaḥ pūrṇimā candraḥ tam svakīyayā śītalayā manohāriṇyā ca śobhayā muṣṇāti yaḥ saḥ khona muṣaḥ
translated: Or, one who steals the full moon, which is empty of the sky, devoid of the sky, full, like the full moon, with his own cool and charming splendor, he too is a sky-stealer.

original: ayaṃ khonamuṣākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ parvatasya pādabhūmāv kham indriyaṃ samākhyātaṃ kham ākāśam udāhṛtam //
analyzed: ayam khonamuṣa ākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ parvatasya pāda bhūmau kham indriyam samākhyātam kham ākāśam udāhṛtam
translated: This region called Sky-stealer is on the foothills of the mountain. The sky is called the sense organ. The sky is said to be space.

original: khaṃ svarge ca samākhyātaṃ khaṃ sarpe ca prakīrtitam /
analyzed: kham svarge ca samākhyātam kham sarpe ca prakīrtitam
translated: The sky is also called heaven. The sky is proclaimed in the serpent.

original: tathā śvabhre ca khaṃ prāhuḥ khaṃ śūnye ca prakīrtitam //
analyzed: tathā śvabhre ca kham prāhuḥ kham śūnye ca prakīrtitam
translated: Likewise, they speak of the sky in a chasm. The sky is proclaimed in the void.

original: adhastād vartate /
analyzed: adhastāt vartate
translated: It exists below.

original: asminn evāsya parvatasyoparitane śikhare bṛhaty ekāntaḥ prakāśarahitā guhā vartate /
analyzed: asmin eva asya parvatasya uparitane śikhare bṛhatī ekāntar prakāśa rahitā guhā vartate
translated: On the upper peak of this very mountain, there is a large solitary cave devoid of light.

original: tasyā guhāyā bhittibhūmiṣu parito devatānāṃ vaddhyo mūrtayaḥ saṃlakṣyante /
analyzed: tasyāḥ guhāyāḥ bhitti bhūmiṣu paritas devatānām vaddhyaḥ mūrtayaḥ saṃlakṣyante
translated: On the walls and floor of that cave, the images of deities are seen all around.

original: tāsāṃ mūrtīnāṃ mukhyatamā ekā mahatī liṅgā kāravatī śivasya mūrtir harṣeśvara ityākhyāṃ sarvamaṇḍalaprakhyātāṃ dhārayantī bhūmau niṣarāṇā dṛśyate
analyzed: tāsām mūrtīnām mukhyatamā ekā mahatī liṅgā kāravatī śivasya mūrtiḥ harṣeśvaraḥ iti ākhyām sarva maṇḍala prakhyātām dhārayantī bhūmau niṣarāṇā dṛśyate
translated: Among those images, one large image of Shiva in the form of a linga, the chief one, bearing the name Harshesvara, famous in all regions, is seen on the ground.

original: asyā guhāyā antare 'nyālpāpy ekā guhāsti /🔽tasyāṃ guhāyāṃ śivasya svacchandākhyā pañcabhir mukhair upaśobhitā mūrtir bahir eva darśanam āgacchati yatas tasyām alpāyāṃ guhāyāṃ praveśo
analyzed: asyāḥ guhāyāḥ antare ekā guhā asti  tasyām guhāyām śivasya svacchanda ākhyā pañcabhiḥ mukhaiḥ upaśobhitā mūrtiḥ bahis eva darśanam āgacchati yatas tasyām alpāyām guhāyām praveśaḥ
translated: Inside this cave, there is another small cave.

original: 'pi sarvathā duṣkaro bhavati /
analyzed: pi sarvathā duṣkaraḥ bhavati
translated: In that cave, Shiva's form named Svacchanda, adorned with five faces, appears only outside, because entering that small cave is very difficult in every way.

original: pūrvaṃ bhasmāsurābhidhasyāsurasya vināśanavelāyāṃ śivena tasyoktadurjātāsurasya vañcanāyai kiṃcit kālaṃ svakīyā mūrtir asyāṃ guhāyāṃ guptatayā 🔽sthāpitā /
analyzed: pūrvam bhasma asura abhidhasya asurasya vināśana velāyām śivena tasya ukta durjāta asurasya vañcanāyai kiṃcid kālam svakīyā mūrtiḥ asyām guhāyām gupta tayā  sthāpitā
translated: Earlier, at the time of destroying the demon named Bhasmasura, Shiva, to deceive that born-evil demon, secretly placed his form in this cave for some time.

original: atha taṃ duṣṭam asuraṃ vināśya yadātena mahān harṣabharaḥ samākalitas tadaiva tena devena harṣeśvara ityākhyā samāsāditā /
analyzed: atha tam duṣṭam asuram vināśya mahān harṣa bharaḥ samākalitaḥ tadā eva tena devena harṣeśvaraḥ iti ākhyā samāsāditā
translated: Then, after destroying that wicked demon, when the god experienced great joy, he attained the name Harshesvara.

original: ato 'sya pradeśasya guhayā śivamoṣaṇaṃ sārthakam evāvagamyate /
analyzed: pradeśasya guhayā śiva moṣaṇam sārthakam eva avagamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that the concealment of Shiva in this region by the cave is indeed meaningful.

original: grāmīṇā ādhunike kāle 'sya khonamuṣākhyapradeśasya khunamoh ityākhya śivamūrtibhedasya harimur iti nāmāpi vadantaḥ santi /
analyzed: grāmīṇāḥ ādhunike kāle khonamuṣa ākhya pradeśasya śiva mūrti bhedasya iti nāma api vadantaḥ santi
translated: Villagers in modern times call this region named Khona-Musa the form of Shiva named Khun-Moh as Hari-Mur.

original: asya harṣeśvarasya kathā harṣeśvaramāhātmye bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitāsaṅkalite vistareṇoktā bhavati /
analyzed: asya harṣeśvarasya kathā harṣeśvaramāhātmye bhṛṅgīśasaṃhitā saṅkalite vistareṇa uktā bhavati
translated: The story of this Harsheśvara is told in detail in the section on Harsheśvara's greatness compiled by Bhṛṅgīśa.

original: asya khonamoṣasya samīpe jayavanaṃ yasya kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ jivan iti nāma prasiddham asti /
analyzed: asya khonamoṣasya samīpe jayavanam yasya kaśmīra bhāṣāyām jivan iti nāma prasiddham asti
translated: Near this Khunamuha village, there is a village famous in the Kashmiri language as Jivan.

original: so 'pi grāmas tathānyo mābur ityākhyo grāmaś ca nikaṭe vartate /
analyzed: saḥ pi grāmaḥ tathā anyaḥ mābuḥ ityākhyaḥ grāmaḥ ca nikaṭe vartate
translated: That village and another village called Mābu are also located nearby.

original: ayaṃ khunamuh ākhyo grāmaḥ vihī ityākhye puragaṇe prasiddhiṃ dhāryamāṇo bhavati /
analyzed: ayam khunamuh ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ vihī iti ākhye pura gaṇe prasiddhim dhāryamāṇaḥ bhavati
translated: This village called Khunamuha is known as a part of the town called Vihi.

original: kaśmīranagarāt pañcakrośadūratāyāṃ grāmo 'yaṃ puragaṇaś cāstīti śam //
analyzed: kaśmīra nagarāt pañcakrośa dūra tāyām grāmaḥ yam pura gaṇaḥ ca asti iti śam
translated: This village and town are located five krośas away from the city of Kashmir. Peace!

original: Daraddeśaḥ
analyzed: darad deśaḥ
translated: The Land of Darada

original: ślokasaṃ namba surendrasya rājño varṇane daraddeśantike /🔽tatra daraddeśanirvacanam /
analyzed: namba sura indrasya rājñaḥ varṇane  tatra darad deśa nirvacanam
translated: In the description of the king Surendrasena, the land of Darada is mentioned in a verse.🔽There, the definition of the land of Darada is given.

original: daradāṃ darajjātīyānāṃ janapadānāṃ yo nivāsasthānaṃ deśa ity asti ca /
analyzed: daradām darad jātīyānām janapadānām yaḥ nivāsa sthānam deśaḥ iti asti ca
translated: The land where the Daradas, the people of the Darada race, reside is called the land of Darada.

original: kaśmīranagaraprāntabhūmau parvatādiṣu nivāsino darat ityākhyā bahavo janapadāḥ /
analyzed: kaśmīra nagara prānta bhūmau parvata ādiṣu nivāsinaḥ darat iti ākhyāḥ bahavaḥ janapadāḥ
translated: There are many countries called Darada inhabited by people living in the mountainous regions on the outskirts of the city of Kashmir.

original: yeṣāṃ āśrayībhūtā bahavo deśāḥ kaśmīrād bahiḥ prāntabhūmiṣu daradāṃ nāmnaiva prakhyātim āgatāḥ santi /🔽tasya ca tair darajjātīyair āśritasya deśasyādhunike kāle kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ dāradin hunu deś iti nāma vadanti /
analyzed: yeṣām āśrayībhūtāḥ bahavaḥ deśāḥ kaśmīrāt bahis prānta bhūmiṣu daradām nāmnā eva prakhyātim āgatāḥ santi  tasya ca taiḥ darad jātīyaiḥ āśritasya deśasya ādhunike kāle kaśmīra bhāṣāyām dāradin hunu deś iti nāma vadanti
translated: Those whose many countries are the basis are known by the name Darada in the border lands outside Kashmir.🔽And in the modern age, they call that country which is the basis of those Darada-like people by the name Dardistan in the Kashmiri language.

original: teṣāṃ ca taddeśanivāsināṃ janānāṃ dārady iti nāma khyātaṃ sarvatraivāsti /
analyzed: teṣām ca tad deśa nivāsinām janānām dāradī iti nāma khyātam sarvatra eva asti
translated: And the name Darad is well-known everywhere for those people who live in that country.

original: tathā nīlamate 'pi
analyzed: tathā nīlamate pi
translated: Similarly, in the Nīlamaṇi, it is said:

original: dārvābhisāragāndhārajuhuṇḍaraśakān khaśān /
analyzed: dārva abhisāra gāndhāra juhuṇḍara śakān khaśān
translated: The Darvas, Abhisāras, Gandhāras, Juhunḍas, Raśakas, Khasas,

original: taṅganān māṇḍavān madrān antargiribahirgirīn //
analyzed: taṅganān māṇḍavān madrān antargiri bahirgirīn
translated: The Tanganas, Māṇḍavas, Madras, Antargiris, Bahigiriṣs.

original: ity uktyā ya ete deśā janapadāśrayībhūtā gaṇitās te darajjātīyā evānumīyante /
analyzed: iti uktyā ye ete deśāḥ janapada āśrayībhūtāḥ gaṇitāḥ te darad jātīyāḥ eva anumīyante
translated: By this statement, it is inferred that these countries which are the basis of the people are of the Darada type.

original: eteṣām anyeṣāṃ cāśrayasthānāni sarvāṇi daraddeśaśabdenaivābhidhīyante /🔽ato 'yaṃ deśaḥ kaśmīrakarājñām ājñāsu sarvadaiva vidheyatayā tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: eteṣām anyeṣām ca āśraya sthānāni sarvāṇi daraddeśa śabdena eva abhidhīyante  atas yam deśaḥ kaśmīraka rājñām ājñāsu sarvadā eva vidheya tayā tiṣṭhati
translated: And all these and other places of residence are referred to by the word Darada country itself.🔽Therefore, this country always remains under the control of the Kashmiri kings.

original: anenaiva hetunā kāśmīrako rājaiva daraddeśājñākṛt sarvadaivāstīty avagamyate //
analyzed: anena eva hetunā kāśmīrakaḥ rājā eva darad deśa ājñā kṛt sarvadā eva asti iti avagamyate
translated: For this very reason, it is understood that only the Kashmiri king is always the ruler of the Darada country.

original: Saurakaṃ Nagaraḥ
analyzed: saurakam nagaraḥ
translated: The city of Saura

original: ślokasaṃ namba surendrasya rājye saurakākhyaṃ pattanam /
analyzed: ślokasam namba sura indrasya rājye sauraka ākhyam pattanam
translated: The verse of the lord of the gods: In the kingdom of the lord of the gods, there is a city called Saura.

original: tatra saurakaśabdasya niruktiḥ /
analyzed: tatra sauraka śabdasya niruktiḥ
translated: Here is the etymology of the word Saura.

original: saḥ kope vāraṇe caiva auṃ kāraḥ syāt tathābrahma aur apy ānanda ucyate /
analyzed: saḥ kope vāraṇe ca eva aum kāraḥ syāt api ānandaḥ ucyate
translated: That which is the syllable Om in anger and in restraining, and also Brahman, is called the bliss of Om.

original: kaś cātmāpi samākhyātaḥ kaḥ pradeśa udāhṛta iti kośavākyāvalambanena saḥ vārako duḥkhāt ya au ānandas tam ānandaṃ rāti dadāti yaḥ sa soraḥ
analyzed: kaḥ ca ātmā api samākhyātaḥ kaḥ pradeśaḥ udāhṛtaḥ iti kośa vākya avalambanena saḥ vārakaḥ duḥkhāt yaḥ ānandaḥ tam ānandam rāti dadāti yaḥ sa sa uraḥ
translated: And that which is called the self, and that which is called the region, depending on the verse of the treasury, that which restrains suffering, that which gives the bliss of Om, that which gives that bliss, is Saura.

original: etādṛśa eva yaḥ kaḥ pradeśaḥ sa saurakaḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśaḥ eva yaḥ kaḥ pradeśaḥ sa saurakaḥ
translated: That which is such a region is Saura.

original: arthāt duḥkhavāraka ānandadāyakaś ca deśaḥ /🔽atha vā sūrasyāpatyaṃ sauropamaḥ śanir vā sopama iva yaḥ prāntaratayā durdarśaḥ kāntārakuñjādimattayā
analyzed: arthāt duḥkha vārakaḥ ānanda dāyakaḥ ca deśaḥ  atha vā sūrasya apatyam saura upamaḥ śaniḥ vā sa upamaḥ iva yaḥ prāntara tayā durdarśaḥ kāntāra kuñja ādimat tayā
translated: In other words, the country that restrains suffering and gives bliss.🔽Or, the son of Sūra is Saura, or like Saturn, which is difficult to see due to being at the edge, and which is like that, having forests and such,

original: ca bhūmāpamāno ta eva śyāmāyamāno malīmasaś ca śanir iva yaḥ kaḥ pradeśaḥ iti vā
analyzed: ca te eva śyāmāyamānaḥ malīmasaḥ ca śaniḥ iva yaḥ kaḥ pradeśaḥ iti vā
translated: and which is dark and dirty like Saturn itself, that which is such a region, is Saura.

original: enam evaitādṛśaṃ pattanaṃ nagaram /
analyzed: enam eva etādṛśam pattanam nagaram
translated: This very such city is that city.

original: pattanaṃ puṭabhedanam ity amaraḥ /
analyzed: pattanam puṭabhedanam iti amaraḥ
translated: Pattanam is puttabhedanam, according to Amarakosha.

original: pūrvavarṇitasya daraddeśasyālike virecitavān sa surendra ity ārthaḥ /
analyzed: pūrva varṇitasya darad deśasya alike virecitavān sa sura indraḥ iti ārthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the lord of gods, having purged the Darada country described earlier, has made it pure.

original: saurakākhyaṃ nagaraṃ kaśmīramaṇḍalavāryasthalavartini daraddeśe rājñā pṛthak sampādinam iti kalhaṇapaṇḍitavacanenaivāvagamyate /
analyzed: sauraka ākhyam nagaram kaśmīra maṇḍala vārya sthala vartini darad deśe rājñā pṛthak sampādinam iti kalhaṇa paṇḍita vacanena evā avagamyate
translated: It is understood from the words of the scholar Kalhana himself that the city called Sauraka was established separately by the king in the Darada country situated in the excellent place of the Kashmir region.

original: tathā hi
analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

original: daraddeśāntike kṛtvā saurakākhyaṃ sapattanam /
analyzed: darad deśa antike kṛtvā sauraka ākhyam sa pattanam
translated: Having made the city called Sauraka near the Darada country,

original: śrīmātvihāraṃ vidadhe narendrabhavatābhidham //
analyzed: śrī mātu hāram vidadhe narendra bhavatā abhidham
translated: the glorious king built the monastery called Narendrabhavata.

original: anyac ca
analyzed: anyat ca
translated: And also:

original: tena svamaṇḍale khaṇḍayaśasā puṇyakarmaṇā /
analyzed: tena sva maṇḍale khaṇḍa yaśasā puṇya karmaṇā
translated: By him, in his own country, with meritorious deeds of limited fame,

original: vihāraḥ sukṛtodāro nirmitaḥ sorasābhidha //
analyzed: vihāraḥ su kṛta udāraḥ nirmitaḥ sorasa abhidha
translated: a very well-made, extensive monastery was constructed, called Sorsaka.

original: ity ādy ukteḥ svamaṇḍale kaśmīrākhye svamaṇḍalād anyatra daraddeśe ca rājño 'sya nirmāṇādikam abhūt /
analyzed: iti ādi ukteḥ sva maṇḍale kaśmīra ākhye sva maṇḍalāt anyatra darad deśe ca rājñaḥ nirmāṇa ādikam abhūt
translated: Thus, it is said that the construction etc. of this king was done in his own country called Kashmir and also in the Darada country, outside his own country.

original: asya saurakākhyasya nagarasya kaśmīrabhāṣāyāṃ hasaur iti prathitatamaṃ nāma sarve kathayanti /
analyzed: asya sauraka ākhyasya nagarasya kaśmīra bhāṣāyām hasauḥ iti prathitatamam nāma sarve kathayanti
translated: Everyone says that the most famous name of this city called Sauraka in the Kashmiri language is Hasur.

original: vartate ca hasaurākhyaṃ nagaraṃ daraddeśe /
analyzed: vartate ca hasaura ākhyam nagaram darad deśe
translated: And the city called Hasura exists in the Darada country.

original: daraddeśasyāpy asya dāradyan hundradeś vā dāradyan hundra mulak iti nāma prasiddham asti /
analyzed: daraddeśasya api asya dāradyan hundradeś vā dāradyan hundra mulak iti nāma prasiddham asti
translated: The name of this country, Darada, is also well-known as Darad, Hund, or Hundrak Muluk.🔽Moreover, those countries of the Hanes, Gilgit, Karnah, etc., although separate from the Kashmir region, are counted within the Kashmir kingdom,

original: punaś ca te ye haṇer gilgith hauja karṇāha ity ādayo deśāḥ kaśmīramaṇḍalāt pṛthaksthā api kaśmīrarājyāntar gaṇitā eva tathaitatmaṇḍalapālakasyājñāpālayamānāḥ 🔽sarvadaiva bhavanti /
analyzed: punar ca te ye haṇeḥ gilgith hauja karṇāhaḥ iti ādayaḥ deśāḥ kaśmīra maṇḍalāt pṛthak sthāḥ api kaśmīra rājya antar gaṇitāḥ eva tathā etad maṇḍala pālakasya ājñā pālayamānāḥ  sarvadā eva bhavanti
translated: and they always obey the orders of the governor of this region.

original: atas tasya rājño 'pi daraddeśe nagaranirmāṇam ucitatamaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: atas tasya rājñaḥ pi daraddeśe nagara nirmāṇam ucitatamam bhavati
translated: Therefore, it is most appropriate for this king to build a city in the Darada country.

original: kecit tu pārisekānuvādavidaḥ saurakākhyam amuṃ pattanam ajānanto buddhibhrameṇa svakapolakalpitakalpanayā
analyzed: kecid tu pāriseka anuvāda vidaḥ sauraka ākhyam amum pattanam a jānantaḥ buddhi bhrameṇa sva kapola kalpita kalpanayā
translated: But some who are knowledgeable in the traditions of the Parishekas, not knowing this city called Sauraka, out of delusion and their own fanciful imagination,

original: ca vṛthotthayā sindhaṣurath ityākhyaṃ kam api pradeśaṃ saurakaśabdābhidheyaṃ parikalpya
analyzed: ca vṛthā utthayā sindhaṣurath iti ākhyam kam api pradeśam sauraka śabda abhidheyam parikalpya
translated: and out of groundless pride, imagine some region called Sindhu Suratha, which is designated by the word Sauraka,

original: rājño sindhuṣurathākhyo deśo nirmita ityādi likhanti /
analyzed: rājñaḥ sindhuṣuratha ākhyaḥ deśaḥ nirmitaḥ ityādi likhanti
translated: and write that the king built a country called Sindhu Suratha.

original: tat sarvaṃ teṣāṃ likhanam asatyatamam asti /
analyzed: tat sarvam teṣām likhanam asatyatamam asti
translated: All that writing of theirs is utterly false.

original: yato rājataraṅgiṇyukte surendrasya varṇane kim apy etādṛśaṃ deśanirmāṇaṃ kvāpi na dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: yatas rājataraṅgiṇī ukte surendrasya varṇane kim api etādṛśam deśa nirmāṇam kvāpi na dṛṣṭam
translated: Because in the description of Surendra given in the Rājataranginī, such a construction of a country is not seen anywhere.

original: ato 'tra prayojanam ajñātvaiva tanmatam astīti budhyate //🔽Narendrabhavanābhidho Vihāraḥ
analyzed: atas tra prayojanam a jñātvā eva tad matam asti iti budhyate  narendra bhavana abhidhaḥ vihāraḥ
translated: Therefore, it is understood that their opinion is that the purpose here is not known.🔽The monastery named Narendrabhavana

original: śloka nambara surendrarājye narendrabhavanābhidhaṃ vihāraṃ /
analyzed: sura indra rājye narendra bhavana abhidham vihāram
translated: In the kingdom of Surendrarāja, there is a monastery named Narendrabhavana.

original: atra narendrabhavanaśabdasya niruktiḥ /
analyzed: atra narendra bhavana śabdasya niruktiḥ
translated: Here is the etymology of the word Narendrabhavana.

original: narāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇām indro rājā narendraḥ /
analyzed: narāṇām manuṣyāṇām indraḥ rājā narendraḥ
translated: Indra of men, the king, is Narendra.

original: narendrasya bhavanaṃ gṛhaṃ narendrabhavanaṃ rājagṛham ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: narendrasya bhavanam gṛham narendra bhavanam rāja gṛham iti arthaḥ
translated: The abode of Narendra is Narendrabhavana, meaning Rajagriha.

original: yathā rājabhiḥ svakīyāni veśmāni svarṇarajataratnātādibhiḥ khacitāni śuddhatamarītyā
analyzed: yathā rājabhiḥ svakīyāni veśmāni svarṇa rajata ratnāta ādibhiḥ khacitāni śuddhatama rītyā
translated: Just as palaces belonging to kings are built by architects with pure craftsmanship, inlaid with gold, silver, jewels, pearls, etc.,

original: kārubhir nirmīyante tathaiva rājñā surendreṇa daraddeśasya nikaṭe hasaurābhidhaṃ
analyzed: kārubhiḥ nirmīyante tathā eva rājñā surendreṇa darad deśasya nikaṭe hasaura abhidham
translated: in the same way, King Surendra, having built a city named Hasaura near the country of Darada,

original: nagaraṃ nirmāya tatraiva narendrabhavanākhyaṃ vihāraṃ bauddhajananivasanādyupayogigṛham ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: nagaram nirmāya tatra eva narendra bhavana ākhyam vihāram bauddha jana nivasana ādi upayogi gṛham iti arthaḥ
translated: there he built a monastery named Narendrabhavana, meaning a house useful for the residence and other purposes of Buddhist people.

original: bauddhānāṃ tu vihāro strī /
analyzed: bauddhānām tu vihāraḥ strī
translated: But for Buddhists, a monastery is a woman.

original: gaṃjā tu madirāgṛham ity amaraḥ /
analyzed: gaṃjā tu madirāgṛham iti amaraḥ
translated: Ganja is a wine house, says Amarasimha.

original: tādṛśaṃ bauddhamandiram api nirmitam /
analyzed: tādṛśam bauddha mandiram api nirmitam
translated: Such a Buddhist temple was also built.

original: vartate cāsya daraddeśamadhyavartino hasaurākhyasya nagarasya nikaṭe narendrabhavanākhyaṃ sthānam /
analyzed: vartate ca asya darad deśa madhya vartinaḥ hasaura ākhyasya nagarasya nikaṭe narendra bhavana ākhyam sthānam
translated: And near the city called Hasaura, located in the middle of the Darada country, there is a place called Narendra Bhavana.

original: tasya ca narendrabhavanasyādhunike kāle kāśmīrakamatena nagūr iti prathitaṃ nāmāsti /
analyzed: tasya ca narendra bhavanasya adhunike kāle kāśmīraka matena nagūḥ iti prathitam nāma asti
translated: And that Narendra Bhavana has a famous name in the present time according to the Kashmiri opinion, Nagur.

original: so nagūrākhyaḥ pradeśo hasaurnikaṭa eva yato vartate 'ta eva narendrabhavanaśabdābhidheyaḥ sa eva pradeśo bhāti /
analyzed: saḥ nagūra ākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ hasauḥ nikaṭe eva yatas vartate te eva narendra bhavana śabda abhidheyaḥ saḥ eva pradeśaḥ bhāti
translated: That place called Nagura shines as the very place called Narendra Bhavana, since it is located near Hasau.

original: ittham eva rājño daraddeśamadhye hasaurnagūrākhyayoḥ pradeśayoḥ svamaṇḍalād vāryasthale nirmāṇam svamaṇḍale nirmitapradeśanirmāṇam agre likhiṣyati
analyzed: ittham eva rājñaḥ darad deśa madhye hasaurnagūra ākhyayoḥ pradeśayoḥ sva maṇḍalāt vārya sthale nirmāṇam sva maṇḍale nirmita pradeśa nirmāṇam agre likhiṣyati
translated: Thus, the king will write in the future about the construction of a place outside his own realm in the two regions called Hasau and Nagura in the middle of the Darada country, and the construction of a place built in his own realm.

original: Sorasaḥ Vihāraḥ
analyzed: sorasaḥ vihāraḥ
translated: The monastery of Sorasa

original: śloka namba surendrasya rājye sorasābhidhaḥ vihāraḥ /
analyzed: śloka namba sura indrasya rājye sorasa abhidhaḥ vihāraḥ
translated: A verse: In the kingdom of the king of gods, there is a monastery called Sorasa.

original: tatra pūrvaṃ sorasaśabdaniruktiḥ /🔽saḥ kope vāraṇe caiveti kośokteḥ /
analyzed: tatra pūrvam sorasa śabda niruktiḥ 🔽saḥ kope vāraṇe ca eva iti kośa ukteḥ
translated: There, first, the etymology of the word Sorasa.🔽Because of the statement in the lexicon that sa means anger and ra means to restrain,

original: sovāraka ūṣpādeḥ pipāsādeś ca tathā ukāraḥ śaṅkare prokta ūkāraś caiva rakṣake iti kośokteś ca /
analyzed: sovārakaḥ ūṣpa ādeḥ pipāsā ādeḥ ca tathā ukāraḥ śaṅkare proktaḥ ūkāraḥ ca eva rakṣake iti kośa ukteḥ ca
translated: The letter u is said to be for protection, and the letter ū is said to be for Śaṅkara, according to the statement in the Kośa.

original: ū rakṣako jīvanam iti yāvat /
analyzed: u rakṣakaḥ jīvanam iti yāvat
translated: Ū is the protector, that is, the life.

original: tathā ca raso gandharase jale śṛṅgārādau viṣe vīrye tiktādau dravarāgayoḥ dehadhātuprabhede ca pāradasvādayoḥ pumān iti medinīkośamatāvalambanena
analyzed: tathā ca rasaḥ gandha rase jale śṛṅgāra ādau viṣe vīrye tikta ādau drava rāgayoḥ deha dhātu prabhede ca pārada svādayoḥ pumān iti medinīkośa mata avalambanena
translated: And in accordance with the view of the Medinīkośa,

original: raso jalaṃ yasya saḥ sorasaḥ /
analyzed: rasaḥ jalam yasya saḥ sorasaḥ
translated: rasa is water, and he who has that is sorasa.

original: atra rasaśabdasya jīvanaṃ bhuvanaṃ vanam ity amaramatena /
analyzed: atra rasa śabdasya jīvanam bhuvanam vanam iti amara matena
translated: Here, by the view of the Amarakośa, rasa means life, the world, and the forest.

original: jalaparyāyeṇa jīvanaśabdena saha samānārthatvād rakṣakajīvanaśabdayoś ca tulyārthatayā rakṣakatvaviśeṣaṇaṃ samīcīnam evāsti /
analyzed: jala paryāyeṇa jīvana śabdena saha samāna artha tvāt rakṣaka jīvana śabdayoḥ ca tulya ārtha tayā rakṣaka tva viśeṣaṇam samīcīnam eva asti
translated: Because the words rasa (water) and jīvana (life) have the same meaning as synonyms, and because the words protector and life have the same meaning, the qualification protector is indeed correct.

original: ato gharmādivārakajalavānayavihārasaṃjñabauddhamandirayutaḥ pradeśa ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: atas gharma ādi vāraka jalava ānayavihāra saṃjña bauddha mandira yutaḥ pradeśaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is a place endowed with a Buddhist temple called gharmādi-vāraka-jala-vānaya-vihāra-saṃjñaka.

original: ādhunike kāle 'sya sorasākhyasya pradeśasya kaśmīrabhāṣayā suras yār iti nāma grāmīṇāḥ kathayanti /
analyzed: ādhunike kāle sya sorasa ākhyasya pradeśasya kaśmīra bhāṣayā iti nāma grāmīṇāḥ kathayanti
translated: In modern times, the villagers call this place Surās Yār in the Kashmiri language, by the name Surās.

original: asmin pradeśe dugdhagaṅgākhyā nadī śītalasparśā madhurāsvādajalā pārvāyatrī ca pravahati /
analyzed: asmin pradeśe dugdhagaṅgā ākhyā nadī śītala sparśā madhura āsvāda jalā pārvāyatrī ca pravahati
translated: In this region, there is a river called Dugdhaganga, with cool touch, sweet-tasting water, flowing down from the mountains.

original: ataḥ soraseti sārthakaṃ nāmāsya eṣā yā dugdhagaṅgākhyā nadī dhārayati /
analyzed: atas sorasā iti sārthakam nāma asya eṣā yā dugdhagaṅgā ākhyā nadī dhārayati
translated: Therefore, this place has the meaningful name of Sorasa, which is the river called Dugdhaganga.

original: asyāḥ kāśmīrakā dūdgaṅgā iti prathitaṃ nāmāsti /
analyzed: asyāḥ kāśmīrakā dūdgaṅgā iti prathitam nāma asti
translated: This river is famous in Kashmir as Dud Ganga.

original: anyad ayaṃ sorasākhyaḥ pradeśo nāgom ityākhye puragaṇe vartate /
analyzed: anyat ayam sorasa ākhyaḥ pradeśaḥ iti ākhye pura gaṇe vartate
translated: This place called Sorasa is located in the group of cities called Nagom.

original: tatrāpi parvatasya pādadeśo bhavati /
analyzed: tatra api parvatasya pāda deśaḥ bhavati
translated: There also, it is a region at the foot of a mountain.

original: asya sorasasya nikaṭe ḍāḍa um pūr tathā mici um pūr ityākhyaṃ grāmadvayaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: asya sorasasya nikaṭe ḍāḍaḥ um pūr tathā mici um pūr ityākhyam grāma dvayam bhavati
translated: Near this Sorasa, there are two villages called Dad Umpur and Mich Umpur.

original: Hastiśālākhyaḥ Agrahāraḥ
translated: The agraharam called Hastishala

original: ślokasaṃ namba rājño godharasya varṇane hastiśālākhyaṃ agrahāram /
analyzed: ślokasam namba rājñaḥ godharasya varṇane hastiśālā ākhyam agrahāram
translated: In the description of King Godhara, there is an agraharam called Hastishala.

original: tatra hastiśālākhyaśabdanirvacanam /
analyzed: tatra hastiśālā ākhya śabda nirvacanam
translated: Here is the explanation of the word Hastishala.

original: hastino śālante śobhante 'treti gajāḥ hastiśālam /
analyzed: hastino śālante śobhante gajāḥ hastiśālam
translated: Elephants shine here, thus it is Hastishala.

original: śālante iti śālyaślāghāyām iti dhāto rūpam /
analyzed: iti śālya ślāghāyām iti dhātoḥ rūpam
translated: The form is from the root shal meaning to shine, with the suffix an for praise.

original: atha vā hastināṃ śālā hastiśālā hastināṃ gṛhaṃ nivasanasthānam iti yāvat /
analyzed: atha vā hastinām śālā hasti śālā hastinām gṛham nivasana sthānam iti yāvat
translated: Or, Hastishala is the abode of elephants, the house of elephants, the place of residence of elephants.

original: etādṛśam agrahāraṃ godhareṇa rājñā nirmitaṃ nirmāya ca viprebhyo dattam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśam agrahāram godhareṇa rājñā nirmitam nirmāya ca viprebhyaḥ dattam iti arthaḥ
translated: Such a place of reception was created by King Godhara, and after creating it, it was given to the Brahmins, this is the meaning.

original: atrāyam āśayaḥ rājño 'sya gṛhe ye madotkaṭā mataṅgajāḥ kariṇyaḥ kalabhāś ca babhūvus
analyzed: atra ayam āśayaḥ rājñaḥ sya gṛhe ye mada utkaṭāḥ mataṅga jāḥ kariṇyaḥ kalabhāḥ ca babhūvuḥ
translated: The idea here is that in this king's house, there were proud elephants, female elephants, and young elephants,

original: teṣāṃ pālanām upayogisthānaṃ yasmād asminn eva pradeśe niyamitaṃ tenāto 'sya pradeśasya
analyzed: teṣām upayogi sthānam yasmāt asmin eva pradeśe niyamitam tena atas pradeśasya
translated: since a place suitable for their care was fixed in this very region, therefore this region

original: hastiśālam ity etādṛśaṃ nāma saṃlagnam /
analyzed: hastiśālam iti etādṛśam nāma saṃlagnam
translated: has the name Hastashala attached to it.

original: vartate ca devasarasākhye puragaṇe hastiśālākhyo grāmaḥ /
analyzed: vartate ca devasarasa ākhye pura gaṇe hastiśālā ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ
translated: And in the group of cities called Devasaras, there is a village called Hastashala.

original: tasya ca devasarasākhyapuragaṇasyādhunike kāle grāmīṇabhāṣāyāṃ devasarpargaṇa ity ākārakanāmāsti /
analyzed: tasya ca devasarasa ākhya pura gaṇasya ādhunike kāle grāmīṇa bhāṣāyām devasarpargaṇaḥ iti ākāraka nāmā asti
translated: And that group of cities called Devasaras has the name Devasarpraguna in the local language in modern times.

original: tathā cāsya hastiśālākhyagrāmasya hasty hel iti sarva viditaṃ nāmāpy asti /
analyzed: tathā ca asya hastiśālā ākhya grāmasya iti nāma api asti
translated: And likewise, this village called Hastashala has the well-known name Hasty-Hel.

original: asya hasty hel grāmasya samīpe kulagrāmākhyo grāmaḥ /
analyzed: asya hastī hel grāmasya samīpe kulagrāma ākhyaḥ grāmaḥ
translated: Near this village Hasty-Hel, there is a village called Kulgrama.

original: sarvasyāsya devasarpargaṇasya mūlagrāmatām adhiṣṭhānatāṃ ca dhārayanyaṃ janāḥ samprati kulgom iti nāmnākārayanti /
analyzed: sarvasya asya deva sarpargaṇasya mūla grāma tām adhiṣṭhāna tām ca dhārayan yam janāḥ samprati kulgom iti nāmnā akārayanti
translated: The people, considering it to be the original village and the foundation of this entire Devasarpraguna, now call it by the name Kulgom.

original: sa grāmaḥ samīpe bhavati /
analyzed: sa grāmaḥ samīpe bhavati
translated: That village is near.

original: kecana asya hastiśālākhyagrāmasya ḍal ityākhyo 'tyantaprathito mahājalāśayo 'yaṃ
analyzed: kecana asya hastiśālā ākhya grāmasya tyanta prathitaḥ mahā jalāśayaḥ yam
translated: Some say that this very famous great water reservoir called Dāl of this village called Hastiśālā

original: phākpuragaṇe sarvakāśmīrakāviditas tathā yasya taṭabhūmiṣu niśātbāg śālabāg ity ādayo
analyzed: phāk pura gaṇe sarva kāśmīraka a viditaḥ tathā yasya taṭa bhūmiṣu niśāt bāc śāla bāc iti ādayaḥ
translated: is known to all Kashmiris in the Phākkapura region, and on the banks of which many very famous gardens such as Niśāt Bāg, Śāl Bāg, etc.

original: mahāprasiddhā ārāmā bahavo 'dhunāpi darīdṛśyante /
analyzed: mahā prasiddhāḥ ārāmāḥ bahavaḥ dhunā api darīdṛśyante
translated: are still seen to be inhabited.

original: tasyaiva jalāśayasyaikasyāṃ taṭabhūmāv anayā hasty hel ākhyayā kathyamāna ekaḥ pradeśo bhavatīti bruvanti /
analyzed: tasya eva jalāśayasya ekasyām taṭa bhūmau anayā hasti hel ākhyayā kathyamānaḥ ekaḥ pradeśaḥ bhavati iti bruvanti
translated: They say that one part of that very water reservoir, called by the name Hasti-hel, is located on one of its bank areas.

original: paraṃ tu yady apy ayaṃ hastiśālākhyapradeśo 'py avaśyaṃ likhita ḍal ityākhyajalāśayasya
analyzed: param tu yadi api ayam hastiśālā ākhya pradeśaḥ api avaśyam likhita iti ākhya jalāśayasya
translated: However, although this region called Hastiśālā is certainly on the bank area of the written Dāl water reservoir,

original: taṭabhūmau haj ratabal iti tattaṭasya pradeśaprathitāgragaṇyapradeśasya kiṃcid dūratāyāṃ
analyzed: taṭa bhūmau iti tad taṭasya pradeśa prathita agragaṇya pradeśasya kiṃcid dūra tāyām
translated: it is a little far from the famous and foremost part of that bank called Hajrat Bāl,

original: tathā tatratyasya āśiyabāg iti sthānasya nikaṭatāyām asty eva tathāpi atratyasyāsya
analyzed: tathā tatratyasya iti sthānasya nikaṭa tāyām asti eva tathā api atratyasya asya
translated: and although it is near the place called Āśiy Bāg there, this

original: hastiśālasya jalaprāyatayāyarthārhāvakāśābhāvādidarśanena ca hastiśālopayogitvāsambhavāc
analyzed: hastiśālasya jala prāya tayā ayarthārha avakāśa abhāva ādi darśanena ca hastiśāla upayogi tva asambhavāt
translated: And because of the water-filled nature of the elephant stable, the lack of space suitable for a temple, and the impossibility of being useful to the elephant stable,

original: ca jalaprāyasya vipreṣu pratipādanānarhatayāpi godharabhūpanirmitaḥ sa eva devasarasapuragaṇamadhyavartī
analyzed: ca jala prāyasya vipreṣu pratipādana anarha tayā api godhara bhūpa nirmitaḥ saḥ eva deva sarasa pura gaṇa madhya vartī
translated: and because of the unworthiness of water-filled land to be given to Brahmins, that very elephant stable named Hrastika, located in the middle of the group of cities of Devapura,

original: hastiśālākhyo 'grahāro bhāti /
analyzed: hastiśālā ākhyaḥ grahāraḥ bhāti
translated: was built by King Godhara and shines.

original: na tv ayaṃ jalaprāyo 'grahāratvavyapadeśasampādanānarho 'nyo hastiśālākhyapradeśa iti /
analyzed: na tu ayam jala prāyaḥ grahāra tva vyapadeśa sampādana anarhaḥ nyaḥ hastiśālā ākhya pradeśaḥ iti
translated: But this other place named Hrastika, which is not water-filled and is unworthy of being called a royal grant, does not exist.

original: aparaṃ ca pārisekānuvādimate 'pi devasarasodbhavasyaiva hastiśālasya godhārabhūpāgrahāranirmāṇaṃ likhitam asti /
analyzed: aparam ca pāriseka anuvādi mate devasarasa udbhavasya eva hastiśālasya godhāra bhūpa agrahāra nirmāṇam likhitam asti
translated: Moreover, in the Pariseka tradition also, it is written that only the elephant stable originating from Devapura was built as a royal grant by King Godhara.

original: na tv asyānyasya phākpuragaṇīyasyeti bhadram //
analyzed: na tu asya anyasya phākpuragaṇīyasya iti bhadram
translated: But this other one, which is included in the group of Phakkapura, is not. This is good.

original: Suvarṇamaṇikulyā🔽ślokasaṃ namba suvarṇasya rājyavarṇane suvarṇamaṇikulyā /
analyzed: suvarṇa maṇi kulyā  namba suvarṇasya rājya varṇane suvarṇa maṇi kulyā
translated: The golden jewel canal🔽In the description of the kingdom of Suvarna, the golden jewel canal is mentioned in the verses.

original: tatra suvarṇamaṇikulyāśabdaniruktiḥ /
analyzed: tatra suvarṇa maṇi kulyā śabda niruktiḥ
translated: There is the explanation of the word golden jewel canal.

original: śobhano varṇo yasya tat suvarṇaṃ kāṃcanaṃ svarṇaṃ suvarṇaṃ kanakam iti maṇīratnam /
analyzed: śobhanaḥ varṇaḥ yasya tat suvarṇam kāṃcanam svarṇam suvarṇam kanakam iti maṇī ratnam
translated: That which has an auspicious color is gold, gold, gold, gold, gold, and jewel.

original: ratnaṃ maṇir dvayor aśmajātau muktādike 'pi cety amaraḥ /
analyzed: ratnam maṇiḥ dvayoḥ aśma jātau muktā ādike ca iti amaraḥ
translated: Ratna and mani are both terms for gems, including pearls and so on, according to Amarakosha.

original: suvarṇasya maṇīnāṃ ca yā kulyālpā nadī kṛtrimā ca /
analyzed: suvarṇasya maṇīnām ca yā kulyā alpā nadī kṛtrimā ca
translated: A small artificial river made of gold and gems.

original: kulyālpākṛtrimā sarit ity amaraḥ /
analyzed: kulyā alpa akṛtrimā sarit iti amaraḥ
translated: A small artificial river is called a kulya, according to Amarakosha.

original: arthāt suvarṇamaṇikulyākhyā nadī tena suvarṇābhidhena rājñā sampāditety arthaḥ /
analyzed: arthāt suvarṇamaṇikulyā ākhyā nadī tena suvarṇa abhidhena rājñā sampāditā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that a river named Suvarna was created by that king named Suvarna.

original: atra suvarṇena maṇibhiś ca yasyās taṭau talasya bhūmiś ca śobhitā nirmitā cābhūd etādṛśī nadī tena pravartitā /
analyzed: atra suvarṇena maṇibhiḥ ca yasyāḥ taṭau talasya bhūmiḥ ca śobhitā nirmitā ca abhūt etādṛśī nadī tena pravartitā
translated: Here, a river of such a kind was started by him, whose banks and bottom were adorned and made beautiful with gold and gems.

original: atha vā suvarṇatulyaśuddhavarṇāmaṇitulyanirmalamanohārijalā ca sā nadī sampanneti sārthakam eva nāmāsyā nadyāḥ sūkṣmekṣikayā avagamyate / atra
analyzed: atha vā suvarṇa tulya śuddhavarṇā maṇi tulya nirmala manohāri jalā ca sā nadī sampannā iti sārthakam eva nāma asyāḥ nadyāḥ sūkṣma īkṣikayā avagamyate atra
translated: Or, it is understood with careful examination that this river has a meaningful name, with water that is pure like gold and charming like gems.

original: tasya sūnuḥ suvarṇākhyas tato 'bhūt svarṇado 'rthinām /
analyzed: tasya sūnuḥ suvarṇa ākhyaḥ tatas bhūt svarṇa daḥ rthinām
translated: Here, his son named Suvarna became the giver of gold to supplicants,

original: suvarṇamaṇikulyāyāḥ karāle yaḥ pravartaka //
analyzed: suvarṇa maṇi kulyāyāḥ karāle yaḥ
translated: who started the Suvarnamanikulya river in Karala.

original: iti paṇḍitakalhaṇaḥ /
analyzed: iti paṇḍitakalhaṇaḥ
translated: Thus says Pandit Kalhana.

original: suvarṇasya rājyavarṇane suvarṇamaṇikulyāṃ vyapadiśya yal likhati /
analyzed: suvarṇasya rājya varṇane suvarṇa maṇi kulyām vyapadiśya yat likhati
translated: When describing the kingdom of Suvarna, he writes about the Suvarnamanikulya river.

original: tatrāvaśyam evāsyāḥ kulyāyāḥ karālābhidhe pradeśe pravartanam itīdṛśy evārthapratītir buddhāvārohati /
analyzed: tatra avaśyam eva asyāḥ kulyāyāḥ karāla abhidhe pradeśe pravartanam iti īdṛśī eva artha pratītiḥ buddhau ārohati
translated: There, the river must certainly flow in a place called Karāla in that valley. Such an understanding of the meaning arises in the mind.

original: paraṃ tu yasmin puragaṇe nady eṣādhunāpi pravahati tasmin sarvasminn eva puragaṇe mahatā yatnenāyāsenāpy anviṣṭāyaṃ ko 'pi karālābhidhaḥ pradeśo
analyzed: param tu yasmin pura gaṇe nadī eṣā adhunā api pravahati tasmin sarvasmin eva pura gaṇe mahatā yatnena āyāsena api anviṣṭā ayam kaḥ pi karāla abhidhaḥ pradeśaḥ
translated: But in that entire city where this river now flows, even after a great deal of effort and search, no place called Karāla

original: grāmo vā kutrāpi na milati /
analyzed: grāmaḥ vā kutra api na milati
translated: or village is found anywhere.

original: ataḥ karālābhidhe pradeśe suvarṇamaṇikulyāpravartanam ity arthapratītir bhramotthātopārthakaiva pratibhāti /
analyzed: atas karāla abhidhe pradeśe suvarṇa maṇi kulyā pravartanam iti artha pratītiḥ bhrama utthā a topārthakā eva pratibhāti
translated: Therefore, the understanding of the meaning the river was caused to flow in a place called Karāla seems to be entirely based on a false meaning.

original: tattvadṛśā tu kaver ayaṃ kalhaṇasyāśayo 'numīyate /
analyzed: tattva dṛśā tu kaveḥ ayam kalhaṇasya āśayaḥ numīyate
translated: But the true view is that this intention of the poet Kalhaṇa is inferred.

original: tatra karālo danturaṃ turo ity amaramatena /
analyzed: tatra karālaḥ danturam iti amara matena
translated: There, Karāla means having sharp teeth according to the Amarakośa.

original: atituṅgo yaḥ ko 'pi pradeśaḥ sa eva karālaśabdābhidheyo bhavati /
analyzed: ati tuṅgaḥ yaḥ pradeśaḥ saḥ eva karāla śabda abhidheyaḥ bhavati
translated: Any very high place is to be designated by the word Karāla.

original: tathā tv eva karāle tuṅgapradeśe rājñā nadī pravartitety arthapratītiḥ samīcīnatamābhāti /
analyzed: tathā tu eva karāle tuṅga pradeśe rājñā nadī pravartitā iti artha pratītiḥ samīcīnatamā ābhāti
translated: In that way, the understanding of the meaning the river was caused to flow by the king in the high place Karāla seems to be the most correct.

original: yata eṣā nadī sarva kaśmīrakabhūmibhyo 'tituṅgāyām ādyāvanibhūmau vartate 'to 'pi karālaparyāyatuṅgabhūmipravartanaṃ nadyā kavyuktaṃ sarvathā
analyzed: yatas eṣā nadī tituṅgāyām ādya avani bhūmau vartate karāla paryāya tuṅga bhūmi pravartanam nadyā kavi uktam sarvathā
translated: Since this river flows in the highest land of all the Kashmir region, therefore the river's flow in the high land called Karāla is in every way

original: saṃgacchate /🔽asyāṃ kaśmīrāyāṃ pūrvam atīte kāle sarovararūpatvenāvasthitāyāṃ yadā kvāpi bhūmir
analyzed: saṃgacchate  asyām kaśmīrāyām pūrvam atīte kāle sarovara rūpa tvena avasthitāyām yadā kvāpi bhūmiḥ

analyzed: eva na babhūva tadā kaśyapa ṛṣi prasādita deva trayī anukampayā ādau yatra eva bhūmiḥ sat jātā
translated: then, by the compassion of the three gods requested by the sage Kaśyapa, when land was first formed,

original: tasyā eva bhūmer adyāvanīty anvarthaṃ nāma saṃlagnam /
analyzed: tasyāḥ eva bhūmeḥ adya avanī iti anvartham nāma saṃlagnam
translated: that very land has the meaningful name Ādyāvanī attached to it.

original: yata ādau bhavā ādyā sā cāsāv avanir avanī vā bhūmir ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: yatas ādau bhavā ādyā sā ca asau avaniḥ avanī vā bhūmiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Because it is the first, it is Ādyā, and it is land, meaning ground.

original: kṣmāvanir medinī mahīty amaraḥ /
analyzed: kṣmāvaniḥ medinī mahī iti amaraḥ
translated: Kṣmāvanī, Medinī, Mahī is Amarakośa.

original: avanī medinī mahīti mediniś ca /🔽atas sarvathāsya puragaṇasyāyasārthaka ādyāvanītyāhvayaḥ /
analyzed: avanī medinī mahī iti mediniḥ ca  atas sarvathā asya pura gaṇasya āyasa arthakaḥ ādyā avanī iti āhvayaḥ
translated: Avani, Medini, Mahī are also Medini.🔽Therefore, this group of cities has the meaningful name Ādyāvanī in every way.

original: asyā cādyāvanipuragaṇasyādhunike kāle nāgarikair grāmīṇaiś ca prakhyāpitaṃ āḍavinpargaṇa iti nāmāpabhraṃśadoṣamūlaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ca adya avanipura gaṇasya ādhunike kāle nāgarikaiḥ grāmīṇaiḥ ca prakhyāpitam āḍavinpargaṇaḥ iti nāma apabhraṃśa doṣa mūlam bhavati
translated: And this name Ādvinparga, which is the basis of the fault of degeneration, is proclaimed by the urban and rural people in the present time of this group of cities Ādyāvanī.

original: yaiṣā suvarṇamaṇikulyākhyā nadī suvarṇabhūparājye suvarṇitāsyāś ca nadyāḥ sunamaṇ kul atha vā sunamaṇ nor iti nāma sarvaprasiddham asti /🔽tatra pūrvapakṣe sunamaṇākhyā kul nadīty arthaḥ /🔽dvitīye tu sunamaṇākhyā nor praṇālīty arthaḥ /🔽dvayoḥ praṇālī payasaḥ padavyām ity amaraḥ /🔽kiṃ tu eṣā suvarṇamaṇikulyākhyā nadī yato 'sya puragaṇasyaikasmin eva grāme na pravahaty ato 'sya niyamitaḥ pradeśaḥ ko 'pi nāsti /🔽asya puragaṇasyānekeṣu grāmeṣu varṇitāyā sunamaṇākhyāyā nadyā jalenaiva sasyādiniṣpattiḥ sambhavati /🔽pārisekānuvādeṣv api te varṇite 'sminn ādyāvanipuragaṇa eva sunamaṇnadyāḥ pravartanaṃ rājñā tatsthānekagrāmasasyaphalaśrīḥ sarvadāsmād ity
analyzed: yā eṣā suvarṇamaṇikulyā ākhyā nadī suvarṇa bhūpa rājye suvarṇitā asyāḥ ca nadyāḥ atha vā iti nāma sarva prasiddham asti  tatra pūrvapakṣe sunamaṇa ākhyā kul nadī iti arthaḥ  dvitīye tu noḥ praṇālī iti arthaḥ  dvayoḥ praṇālī payasaḥ padavyām iti amaraḥ  kim tu eṣā suvarṇamaṇikulyā ākhyā nadī yatas pura gaṇasya ekasmin eva grāme na pravahati atas sya niyamitaḥ pradeśaḥ na asti  asya pura gaṇasya anekeṣu grāmeṣu varṇitāyāḥ sunamaṇa ākhyāyāḥ nadyāḥ jalena eva sasya ādi niṣpattiḥ sambhavati  pāriseka anuvādeṣu api te varṇite smin ādya avanipura gaṇe eva sunamat nadyāḥ pravartanam rājñā tad sthāna eka grāma sasya phala śrīḥ sarvadā asmāt iti
translated: This river called Suvarṇamaṇikulyā is golden in the Suvarṇa kingdom, and the name of this river is well-known as Sunamana or Sunamana.🔽In the first case, the meaning is the river named Sunamana.🔽But in the second, the meaning is the canal named Sunamana.🔽The canal of two rivers is the meaning.🔽However, this river called Suvarṇamaṇikulyā does not flow in even one village of this group of cities, so it has no restricted region at all.🔽The production of crops etc. is possible only by the water of the river named Sunamana in many villages of this group of cities.🔽Even in the restatements of the Pariśeka, the starting of the Sunamana river in this very first city of the earth is described by the king, and the prosperity of the crops in that one village is always from this.
